A.C. Pierce, Abstractor. ESTABLISHED 1856   Harry Pierce, Surveyor.
A. C. Pierce's
Land, Loan, Abstract and Insurance Office
Junction City, Kansas 11-17 1902
J E Everett Esq
Dear Sir,

  I believe it would be a good thing to impeach the County Attorney of this Co. I think it could be done. Of course we have an election next spring and possibly the town might be carried for a Loyal Mayor and Council if it could a Marshall would be appointed by him and then of course the Saloons would be closed. If the new Atty General intends to do his duty according to his oath of office and almost any kind of a man ought

to do it of course he can shut up quickly every Saloon in the State. The Republican Party cant afford to let Saloons run wide open in any City in the State in my judgment They will find if they if they let the Saloon run that it will be a heavy load sooner or later they will find Saloons are a heavier load than Slavery ever was and that question damned the Democratic Party for a generation at least and the end is not yet. I have no respect for office holders who will perjure themselves for a Saloon or for any other purpose. I hope the Republican Party will do their duty the coming year will they do it. Yours? A C Pierce

Dear Mr Everett, -  

 I am not surprised that you wrote as you did when I recall the many criticisms I so thoughtlessly made the evening you called.  I have not the shadow of an excuse to make for myself. May the Fates smile upon you Monday as your absence will deprive both Josephine

and myself of pleasure.
Your friend,
J.E.B. Bedford
Clinton, N.Y
June 8, 1888.

HIRAM H. BICE
2 ASHFORD AVENUE
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.
May 2, 1926.
My dear John: -
I read your letter with much joy so glad to hear from an old friend like you after so many years. I heard from you when you were in Kansas and I wrote to you to an address that you seemed to have on Riverside Drive in New York. I do not recall now what the explanation was.
I hear very little about Utica now. My sister still lives there and I visit her when I can, but otherwise I have no longer any interest there except in the cemetery. When I was there last I heard that Miss Pringle was still living, now nearing one hundred!
I was interested in what you said about your daughter, Mary. If she wishes to teach in New York

she will have to pass the city examination for a license. This will necessitate a visit to the city at the time of the test. She can find out all the details of the matter from the Board of Examiners, 500 Park Ave., New York.

 Of course I cannot speak of her teaching ability, but I should be glad to introduce her to any one whom I know, as the daughter of my old friend.
 When I have a chance I shall drop in to see your sons. I am very busy now. We have just leased our house at the address above, have given it up and moved to 390 Broadway, Yonkers, where we shall be till June 30, when we board the Homeric for a trip to the other side which may last six months. The length depends on my securing a sabbatical leave of six months from my work here.
 I have one son, now twenty-five years old, who lives in Washington, being connected with the United States Chamber of Commerce. We are hoping that he

2/
HIRAM H. BICE
2 ASHFORD AVENUE
DOBBS FERRY, N.Y.
may go with us on our trip. He cannot of course remain away longer than a few weeks.

 How did you get my address as above? I remember very well my trips to Remsen. Do you remember Robert Hughes? I saw him about ten years ago. He did not look like the "Bob" I used to know. The world has not been good to him, or the other way round. I was sorry.
 With affectionate regard from your old friend.

Cordially yours.
Hiram H. Bice.
Write to me again.

Osawatomie Miami Co Kas
Dec 9th, 1883
Friend Eddie,

 I thought I would write you a little. Your father is sick in bed, was taken down this morning has some fever. He wants you to get your Aunt to send him some medicine. He has been ailing of about one week but nothing serious. His symptoms are being chilly while up and around. I will see to your father the best that I can! If he is not better by morn he will get Dr Jacobs to come and see him. We are having splendid weather at present.

From your friend
Lyman Bullock

P.S. Your father has nux vomica Carbo. Acconi and byonia but has no Rush. he thinks that it would be good for a cold. Your father is swetting pretty freely at present I think that is a favorable symptom. I hope he may will be better in the morning.
L.E.B
Dec 18th 1883
Good morning, Edd

 Your father rested well last night and is a great deal this morning. I think he will make it all right. 

Lyman E. Bullock

Osawatomie, Dec 12, 83
"Dear Eddie - Your father's fever arose about 6 last evening he had a considerable fever all night. some this morning. but not as heavy as it was during the night. Your father thinks he feels pretty stout this A.M. (8.20 o'clock.) He is taking Bry and Carbo Veg. and Nux alternately an hour apart. The fever is not as heavy as it was on Sunday, with no accompanying symptoms of being chilled as he was on the Sabbath day. Your father thinks perhaps the medicine may lose its strength by standing too long. We will call Dr. Jacobs in during the day, if he passes along. Keep up courage. Your friend L.E.B" 
The second letter is also dated Dec 12 but I think it is a mistake. Should be 13th 
"Dear Eddie, - this morning finds it raining

with the temperature somewhat lower than it has been for some time. Your father was quite nervous during the fore part of the night. but after 10 o'clock he began to rest and sleep a little better than he did before that time. This morning he seems to be pretty well - is resting very well. with less fever. The Dr. was here last evening. He thought your father was in no danger and doing well as could be expected. Your father has a slight hacking cough, but not at all irritating. Eddie, your father wants some more Bry. and Rhus tox. sent right away. 
From your friend, Lyman Bullock 
If there should be any danger I will send for you."

The CHRISTIAN CENTURY
A JOURNAL OF RELIGION
508 South Dearborn St., Chicago
Oct. 3, 1922
Rev. Edward Everett,
Overbrook, Kansas 
Dear Sir:
Enclosed you will please find your manuscript, "I Go to Conquer a City," which Mr. Morrison desires me to say he has read with much interest. However, the pressure on our columns is so great at the present time that it is quite clear it will be impossible to find space for it.
We are compelled to decline many more manuscripts than we are able to publish and in your own case we do so reluctantly. This declination does not imply anything at all as to the character of your manuscript which Mr. Morrison has found in every way a worthy and helpful production.
Yours very truly,
THE CHRISTIAN CENTURY
Lucy E. Rogers
Secretary to Mr. Morrison

Dec 6 - 1923
The Rev. J.E. Everett
Overbrook,
Kansas.
Dear Mr Everett, 
At the annual meeting of the Congregational Church here on Jan 3rd it was voted to extend a call to you as pastor of the church at a salary of #1500 a year and parsonage. It is expected of the pastor called that he keep the morning service, Sunday School, & Christian Endeavor in running condition.

Please let us know as soon as convenient, our church is to be supplied by Rev Conley during January.
Sincerely Your's 
Mrs R. P. Yale
Clerk.

other handwriting:
From 
Russell Dana an old schoolmate of mine in C.C. N.Y. 1880-'81
J.E.E.
New York Nov. 19th / 81
Dear Everett,
I am indeed sorry to see that you have been the one who would break the agreement that we made before you left but I will freely forgive you if you will write me a letter equivalent to those I sent you. 
Both Elder and I are getting along well in our studies. Elder's average in math is about 90 & general average about 80. My marks for last fortnight are as follows. Greek, 96, Latin 93, English 50, Math 86, Botany 85, History 83, Descriptive Geometry 92. My average being a little over 83. I must do better in English & then I will be doing famously. I do not know Huber's marks but if I go to see him this afternoon I will affix them to my letter under the

name of P.S. 
I have had but 5 demerits so far; don't fail to congratulate me about this in your letter (which is soon to come I hope). For Draper's deafness + Johnston's good nature opportunities not to be neglected. In Draper's room we sometimes have lots of fun scaring the Subs (subfresh) When Stratford is out, the Subs talk + sing + chalk flies around as if possessed. Suddenly one of our fellows at the board pushes back a sliding door + utters a few words in Stratfords tone. How silent the Preps become! O how they are scared! You know how the Freshmen used to annoy Stratford last year by tapping with chalk on the panels? Well, we do the same - only a little worse.
I have give your auntn a Merit roll + sundry Mercuries. Have you rec'd them yet? I am sorry to hear that your aunt is so sick and hope that through

your care she will greatly improve.
Our football team played Rutgers on Thursday last, + got badly kicked. Ten goals + seventeen touchdowns to nothing. Of course as we can not practice much, it is not surprising that we should be beaten by teams that practice nearly every day of the week. But we have the spirit + the will, + if the faculty would only buy or hire some grounds, we would send forth a bad team, I assure you. 
The cane we won in a rush from '84 will soon be put up for another rush between the classes. But by our numbers + our pluck we hope to be able to retain it. 
Morganthau gives us nearly a page of Latin (Sallust) a day. We are having a hard time of English under Burchard's care (compositions &c &c &c). Elder has another bee buzzing in his hat. When you went away he was trying to make a Rhumkoff's coil; now it is another kind of portable boat
sideways in margin: Presbyterians

Keep quiet on this subject, he might be a little sensitive on this. 
You can't imagine how I miss those long walks we used to have +, if I live to be as old as Methusaleh I could never forget the walk we took up to High Bridges with 8 cts between us three. I could fill numbers of foolscap pages with this nonsense. But for fear you should tire, I drop off here. Again + for the last time, I bid you answer my letters. Dye hear? 
I am (conditionally) your faithful friend. 
Russell
Huber says his marks had better remain in oblivion.

New York July 25/83
Dear Eddy,
If you desire to answer my letter, I will be reached by addressing as given below until the 6th of August. If you do write, tell me what inducement you will give me to come up there for the fall + winter + work on the farm with you.
Yours in friendship,
Russell
C/o H.H. Jackson
Stormville, Duchess Co, New York.

Waterville, Nov. 1. 1885
My dear friend
I don't know as you care to receive a letter written on Sunday but this is the third attempt I have made and if I do not write tonight it will be left another week to trouble me, for an unanswered letter is a very troublesome thing.
Your letter was received nearly a month ago. I had not realized how fast the time was passing till I looked at the date of your letter. I have been quite busy ever since I came from Remsen which has been good for me I know, for I get lonesome and homesick well into my work, and it would be much worse I am sure if I had more time to think. We have been making some changes in the course of study, and in order to follow the program we have been

obliged to change some classes, so that it seems as if we had hardly commenced work and here it is November and it will soon be Thanksgiving. I suppose you are going home then? I shall begin to count the days now. I wish I might stay longer but shall be glad to get home even for as short a time. I think I shall have to take "Margery Dan" with me, and let you read if if you have not already. I am sure you will like it.
In regard to the bureau cover. I think you were hardly fair, to say, you supposed. I had begun to hope you had forgotten. I was quite sure you would remember, so what would be the use of hoping for the impossible. 
Have you any amount of patience? And do you like to exercise that beautiful virtue? Because if you do not possess this gift, I advise you to get it somewhere for you will need it while waiting for the present you so persistingly "begged." I shall be glad to make it

and intend to, but just when I cannot tell. I am making mittens at present, during week days I mean of course. and those must be finished before I take up any other work. I am such a rapid knitter, I think my mittens will be finished some time in '86. Then, if I am as long making the cover, you may look for it about the time you graduate. So you see how necessary it is for you to cultivate patience. 
I was glad to know that they missed me a little at home. but they must be getting over being lonesome for I haven't had a letter from there in over a week. Time for me to go back again - just to remind them of their loss. 
Did our snowstorm reach Clinton? Yesterday the ground was white, and it looks quite wintry yet. It seems early for winter we are hardly ready for it but I suppose we must take the weather as it comes. Now I must write a letter home. Trusting you will not get discouraged and

your patience will hold out.
Remain your friend
MJ. Davies

Metaline Falls, Wa. 
Feb. 21st, 1915. 
My dear Edward,
By this time I suppose Mary is thru being measley, and you and Margaret are home again. I wonder if you or Margaret are having them now, or whether you have escaped. It broke up the rooms at school quite badly, did it not?

Do you still like your watch that you got from the Curtis Publishing Co.? and what is a brown voucher? 
Is Charlie Pearle still with you? Margaret wrote some time a go that he is to be married soon. 
I am still wondering whether you and Margaret are taking piano lessons. Do you still play duets? 
I have been here in Metaline Falls just five months; and am just beginning to feel acquainted with the folks here, and before another month is passed I expect to be in Spokane, at home with the folks. If all goes well I shall visit a school friend who lives on a ranch: I suppose I ought to say, a friend of my school days, we were in the 8th grade together. She has been married for ten years! I shall hate to leave these great mountains, i love them so. The river I shall not miss quite so much, as the Spokane river runs right thru the center of Spokane

and there are several pretty falls right down town, we cross the river every time we do down town from home. 
Edward, I surely am enjoying the Ladies Home Journal very much. I must write tonight to Curtis Pub. Co. + tell them of my change of address. I hope you are all well. Give Mary my love, + with love to you, I am
Your Friend
Lilie Dehuff.
E. 1017 La Crosse Ave.
Spokane, Wa.

PETER GURTLER, PRESIDENT. F. B. LANDON, VICE PRESIDENT. W. H. PAULY, TREASURER.
The Onaga Commercial Club
J.W. DUNN, Secretary.
Rev. J. E. Everett, Onaga, Kansas, Oct. 30th, 1902.
Topeka, Kansas.
Dear Bro. : -
Yours of 27th inst. is at hand and noted. In reply I will say that I do not know much about how money matters are going at the bank, because I have been out in the campaign nearly all the time for a month. But, in a general way, I know that all loanable funds are being rapidly tied up in cattle paper. We have a good corn crop and farmers are borrowing all the money in the banks with which to purchase cattle to feed. Therefore, I think real estate money will be pretty scarce until next summer. I mean that local capital will be invested in cattle paper at better rates that real estate loans. But I have no doubt that these fellows that loan eastern money on real estate will have plenty of it to place on good risks. I will look the field over here and if I can find any one desiring to invest, I will let you know. I do not think that our bank can handle any more real estate loans until next spring.
I suppose that you will be interested to know that Mr. Hess has paid for the old horse and your account has credit for $31.50, making your balance with us $32.50. You can draw this at any time you desire, or we can send it to you upon your order.
Politically speaking, I think I am on top. But I shall know about that soon. I am not scared.
We are all well as usual. Mrs. Dunn and I expected to be in Topeka and see you about a week ago, but we were unable to make the trip. Don't know when we can come now. Best wishes to you all.
Yours Truly,
J.W. Dunn

Kingston Pa 
Feb 2 / 18
Rev John Edward Everett
Overbrook Kansas. 
Dear Brother Everett,
Thank you very sincerely for your kind letter and the Book of your Poems. I have very sweet recollections of the Everetts at Steuben and in New York City. I edited a Department of the Cenhadwr while it was published by Mr Lewis Everett, before the Sale of it to Rev. Edward Davies. I commenced my pastoral charge of the Welsh Cong'l Ch. of Edwardsville, Jan 1. 1878 I was absent for the greater part of 2 yrs; 1891-1893. I am the only Pastor of the Church for 40 yrs. 
I will mail you our Directory which came from the printers this week. 
I enjoy your "Whittlings"; they have in them the sparks of wit and the hue of poetic genius.
Kindest regards and  best wishes.
Your? Cynonfardd
Cynonfardd = former poet

Kingston Pa Mch 21/18
Dar Bro Everett: 
The last volume that I know of on the lines of your inquiry is - 
"Welshmen as Factors"
Published by the "Y Drych," Utica, NY It is the Prize Essay at the International Eisteddfod of Chicago in 1893. by Rev. Ebenezer Edwards, who wrote under the name of "Wm Penn." Mr Edwards was a Baptist Minister. He died in Allentown Pa, 12 yrs ago. There is a later Essay on the same theme published in "The Blue Book containing the Compositions of the
Y Drych = The Mirror

Pittsburgh International Eisteddfod of 4 yrs ago; but that book is not on the market. It was sold to "Subscribers only". You will find "Welshmen as Factors" very interesting; tho it is not "up to the minute." You can write for it to
Thos J Griffiths, 
Publisher "Y Drych"
Utica N.Y.
Glad to hear from you. 
Kindest regards unknown
your Cynonfard

CIRCULAR LETTER TO
THE WELSH CONGREGATIONAL CHURCHES
OF THE UNITED STATES
AUGUST, 1917.
The undersigned were appointed by the Eastern Association of Welsh Congregationalists to prepare a Welsh-English Congregational Hymnal (Emynydd Cynulleidfaol Cymreig Seisnig), a Hymnal to meet the needs of the Congregational Churches in our district in their transitory state from Welsh to English, and the need of other Churches in their bilingual condition. The action of the Gymanfa is its sessions at Tabernacle, Scranton in September, 1916, was endorsed by the Quarterly Meeting held at Wilkes-Barre, June 9, 1917, and the original Committee was urged to go on with the project. They called representatives of the Churches to meet at Pittston to discuss the question and to receive suggestions, and in this meeting a number of able men were asked to co-operate with them, and we hereby acknowledge our gratitude to Mr. Oliver Rhydderch of Edwardsville and Mr. Gomer Rees of Plymouth for their work and labor of love. This work is the result of our conferences and deliberations. We have endeavored to avoid surplus matter in its preparation. We sought a Hymnal not to adorn our pews, but to serve our Congregations in their devotion and worship, quality not quantity has been our motto. We have attempted to retain the tunes that bear the characteristics of the Welsh people, and have yoked them to the best available English Hymns so that the younger generations may learn and sing the Hymns and tunes that have been the means of such rich spiritual blessings to their ancestors, and have marked the nation as being one of the foremost in their Congregational singing. It will be a valuable connecting link between the past, present, and future generations. It will contain not less than 140 of the best tunes of present and past composers and over 400 of the choicest Hymns suitable for all seasons and occasions in the Christian year. It will be published in two bindings and sold for 50 and 75 cents respectively. It will also contain several commendable features that are to be found in the leading Hymnals of the larger denominations in this and in the old country, such as the Apostle's Creed, the Congregationalists declaration of faith, the ten Commandments, the Lord's Prayer and several forms of benediction, together with about thirty pages of responsive readings in Welsh and in English.
No labor has been spared to make it a most valuable contribution to our Churches in their present condition. We offer it with great confidence that it will meet with the approval of all unprejudiced minds, and that it will add to the dignity and efficiency of our praise. Our Churches and others who are in need of a good substantial and inexpensive Hymnal are invited to correspond and send their orders to the Secretary of the Committee.
Yours in the Master's service,
REV. T. CYNONFARDD EDWARDS. D.D.,
MR. W.D. OWENS,
REV. DAVID JONES, Secretary.
123 South Lincoln Avenue,
Scranton, Pa.

Rev. T. C. Edward, D.D.

Conanicut Park
July 24/83
My Dear John: 
I am happy to say, that after the lapse of some time, the feeling of friendship is still strong; as I intend it always shall be. Now, on the strength of this; please write me a letter, and let me know what has happened since the 'auld lang syne.'

I am real sorry that I was not in N.Y. when you were there. I suppose Dana and Huber tried to make your short visit full of interest to you. I am on an island in Narragansett bay, spending my vacation. 
Your friend, 
Address 

Joseph A. Elder

Conanicut Park
Newport.
R.I.

Clinton Oneida Co.,
N.Y. July 17th, 1912
Dear Mr. Everett:
I am in receipt of yours 8th 9th and am happy to be reminded of an old friend and of my happy boyhood days. 
I should be glad to receive your son and to serve him

to have your son call on me at 336 W 86th St. where I live and shall do my upmost to help him.
Father passed away Dec 24th 1900, at the age of 78. He died peacefully at the home of my sister Mrs. Albert Morgan then living at OshKosh Wis. 
You have an excellent memory. "Ich Dien" 
Ich Dien = German for I Serve

if I were in New York for your sake and for his. Every young man who comes to the great city has my sympathy and I welcome the opportunity to serve any that come in my store. I left the city at the beginning of July to be gone until the middle of September. Once I return I shall be pleased

The motto of the Prince of Wales was the subject of my Commencement oration at Holland Patent Academy.
I appreciate your reference to the devotion I had for my mother. I lover her dearly and her sweet and patient life is often present to my consciousness. 
With best wishes for your prosperity in the ministry, and hoping to meet your son in autumn, John, cordially yours,
A.H. Evans

THE FOLLOWING POEM is printed by request The author's name is not known
'Plodding is hard when the pathway is rough,
Smiling is hard when your neighbors are gruff,
Patience is hard when the spirit is tried,
Working is hard when rest is denied:

 But who ever promised you ease?

Sleeping is hard in your wakeful hours,
Waking is hard when sleep overpowers,
Saving is hard when your wages are poor,
Planting is hard with the fruitage not sure;

 But who ever promised you ease?

Meet the world bravely and all there is in it;
Joy, if at times you are able to win it,
Sorrow, if that is your lot and your share,
God has not promised you freedom from care;

 God has not promised you ease."

My dear Everett: -
It may interest you to see that one of your songs has become a winged word and is flying about anonymously. The entry in the enclosed calendar was taken in this form from another calendar of a church near New York. Hoping that all is going well with you I am, with sincere personal regards,

Concord N.H.
May 24th 1883.
My Dear Classmate.
Thank you for the postal received. The reminder of duty. very sorry I needed it. I did not receive one in March. 
And first let me thank you for your labor of love for the Class. It is no small task. take as much pleasure in it as you may. and i know your hands must be full judging from the last report of you. Isn't this a busy world. Jennie,

It was an unexpected pleasure and a great joy to have the reading of the class letter a few months since. forwarded from our dear Lucy Mills Brooks. I felt all were growing and doing more than proud. My work is mostly in my home. The time of the scattering from the nest has come. and the four children spared are grown and away, coming home often as vacations bring them The three sons. have graduated from Dart. Coll. The youngest of them graduating next month. All have sought considerably but are not yet settled in their life work. Jennie, our daughter of eighteen is at Abbot Academy with Miss McKeen

entered Senior Middle and will probably return and finish next year.
With a heart full of gratitude I record the mercies of the year. In August my husband was taken sick and for ten weeks was confined to his bed. much of the time dangerously sick. His life was spared. a wonder to all, and he is about his work, which you remember is Sec. of S.H. Horne Miss So. He is now pretty well, though not having fully recovered his strength.It was a great comfort that the sons could be home and we could take the whole care of him.
My own health is quite good. better than some years ago

My love to all the dear classmates. I wish they would bear in mind that Concord is my home and give me a call.
Now, Jennie, excuse that I have written so much cut out all you please. 
I was much interested to hear about your sisters work in N.Y. Hope you will tell us more about it. With much love,
Yr. off. classmate,
L.M. More.Greeley
Concord, N.H.

My dear Everett,
Was glad to see your name on the Clark Prize programme & glad to have you remember me.  But distance was too great an obstacle this time.  I notice the prize escaped you but the honor of being on is large enough.
By the Observer which reaches me here I learn that the boys are getting away with lots of honors & prizes.  The DU's in your
transcriber's note: DU's = members of Delta Upsilon, JEE's fraternity.

Yours sincerely
Leslie R. Groves

Perryville Ohio March 6 -- 1918
Please excuse blots  my pen leek:s at times
Mr and Mrs P C should be J E Everett Overbrook Kansas
My Dear dear friends

    Have taken up my pen, to talk awhile with you, this afternoon, myself doing all the talking, and first I must apologise for my long delay, in answering your xmas greetings, which were so gladly received  The delay was not intentional, I assure you, for when it came, I promised myself I would reply very soon, but you probably know how easy it is, to put things off until tomorrow, that should be done to day, and I find it is much easier for me, than it was when I was younger, and then too, I have grown so nervous? in the last year, or two, I can scarcely write a legible hand any more

so if you can not decipher this, you must consign it to the waste basket, and simply take the "will for the deed" I was so glad to hear from you, again, but was sorry to know, that Mrs Everett's health was not good, but hope when the "spring time comes" and we can be out of doors more, and able to breath a pure healthful "moral" atmosphere" we will all feel better.  It has been a hard winter on "shut in:s," especialy on old people  I have a sister who lives 2nd door from me, her husband was a soldier in the Civil war, and was 78 years old, his last birthday, has not been out of the house this winter, has been the greater part of the time, so that he could walk about the house, until the last few days, and when he does not keep in bed he reclines in his wheel chair and does not seem as if he

2

would be with us, many days, but I think he is prepared for the change that awaits us all  Has been an elder and an active member in the Presbyterian church for many years and will be greatly missed  We have had the coldest winter for many years, so much snow, in fact, the ground has been covered the greater part of the winter, and one or two days, the mercury registered as low as 20 below zero, the snow a good part of it, at least went off with a rain and the roads are almost impassable.  We had a light fresh full of snow last night, and while the sun is shining, the air is so cold, I think the snow will remain until it is warmer.  I think so much about the Soldiers who are in camp, for I think they surely can not be comfortable and some I know have fallen victim

of Pneumona, and brought back to be laid away by their parents. We have three great nephews in the army one went from Calif. one from Ind and one from Ohio.  You spoke in Your letter of Roberts going into the army and I have wondered whether he went as a soldier, or as a correspondent to some paper and I would be glad to know where he is located.  Have been doing some red cross work, But I was late commencing and am slow with the needles  Just finished the 7th pair of socks last evening, but it is getting late, and I want to write to Margaret yet this evening  Please remember me to the rest of the family, and I would like to hear from you whenever it is convenient for you to write with kind regards for all am as ever a real friend

                                                     Anna E Irvine

PS a sister of mine is with me

You see I have things badly mixed up, I was not certain about Margaret's address, and concluded I would better put it in with yours, and meant to write this on your part of the letter, and instead of that, I got it on her part, I hope you will get it straightened out all right, and next time I will try not to make so many mistaks am realy ashamed to send it 

 A

My dear little Margaret and Edward
I have just finished writing to your Mama, and thought I could not finish up without writing some to you and Edward,  We were so glad to get your letter, and I did not intend to be so long answering it, but have been quite busy, we think of you daily, and wish we could see you.  You ought to be here now we have so much nice sweet corn, and the nicest Tomatoes, and you could have all the Peaches and Grapes you could eat.  The eight little turkeys are all liveing and growing nicely, and I have not for-

gotten that I promised to roast one for you, if you would come down at Thanksgiving time Mr. Irvine says to tell you, that Pim? and her kittens all went away, pretty soon after you did, and we have never seen them since  You have not seen them have you?  I guess he thought maybe they had started to follow you.  How is little Mary now, I hope she is feeling better, than when she was here, but I must stop for this time, hoping to hear from you soon.  Mr. Irvine has just come in with some nice rose Peaches, wish I could send you some, in this letter.   Your loving friend Anna Irvine

Perrysville Ohio March 1918
Dear dear Margaret I wonder if you can and will forgive my long delay I little thought when your last thrice welcome letter was received that I would allow so much time to be bourne away on the wings of time, before commencing a reply - No indeed I planned to reply immediately. but somehow I dont get things done as I used to, or as I plan too. I used to be, I could hurry around, and get my work done, and have time to write but of late I dont seem to have any leisure. My time is all consumed in the little bit of work I have to do, and yet it is quite a bit too, for an old lady past 80 years old. Have been doing a little at red cross work, and am with that, as
added at top:
And I will just put Margaret's letter in with this. and you can send it to her I am not quite certain as to her Topeka address

I am at every thing else, quite slow, but my eyes do not serve me very well, or I might accomplish more. Am so glad that you can be in college at Topeka this year, and I hope you may be able to continue through the course, but even if you can not go longer than this year, it will be a great help to you, and I wish your success in whatever you undertake yes I remember Beth Hays very well, she was only a little girl, or rather a miss as I remember her at Serez?.  Kind regards to her, and best wishes for her success, in whatever she plans to do, in the future Where is Beth, I suppose she has finished school and is probably engaged in teaching, or she may have chosen some other work, there are so many avaneus open to girls now that one is not obliged to choose something that is distasteful or something for which they have no likeing

and I wonder what you may engage in, when you are through with your school work Well whatever it may be I hope it will be to your liking and that you may be successful in whatever kind of work, you may engage in if it should be, to remain at home, and assist your dear mama, who has done so much for you, when you was just a little girl. I often live over the good times we used to have, when you would be with us, They were red letter days or rather weeks to me and I should never forget them while I am in the flesh and Roberts too, how well I remember him. Your Father wrote me that he was married and would soon be in the army. Well my prayer is that his life may be spared, and that he may be returned to his home

Do you remember Arly Brunlz? His Mother writes to me, that he is in the army. He is the only child too you know, and it is very hard for her to give him up. This is such a dark, gloomy day, and I think my feelings partake somewhat of the nature of the weather, for my being seems not to have a thought in it, and as it is almost chore time, think I will have to close for the present, and finish another time. Now will you not excuse this poorly written letter, and write me very soon my pen leeks at times, and has made so many blots and do please excuse my long delay, and I will try to do better next time With much love and good wishes for you 
Am as ever your loving friend Anna E. Irvine

I often think what a lonely being I would

Moravia N.Y. May 13th /26
My dear Everett; It was my hope that by delaying an answer to your welcome letter of so long ago that I might be able to report something worth while for Miss Mary. I spoke to the princeipal of our school here about a position and also asked him to keep me informed in case he heard of anything worth while Elsewhere. Most of the positions seem to be filled thru School Agencies which have a faculty of hearing about vacancies and then filing applications for those who register with them. Up to date the principal has heard of no vacancies. There was one in our school for Chemistry and biology but alas your daughter didn't speak of these branches as the ones in which

she was proficient. I hope by this time that she has found some thing along her line which will be a stepping stone to a better place a little later. It was a real pleasure to hear from you and to learn of your welfare. I tried out my work first in Minn not far from Cannon Falls, Red Wing. Have preached in the Congregational Church at Zumbrota so know something of the state as it used to be before I had any gray hairs. Only yesterday I read a map from some Power Company, Northern States I believe which included Red Wing in its territory and as I saw the name the thought suggested itself that I'd like to revisit the place again. Unfortunately, the likelihood is too remote to warrant my saying in case I did so Id run over the prairie and visit John.

Life has dealt very kindly with me since I left College in the matter of health and home. My wife and I are living in one of the most beautiful locations in the state, right in the heart of the Finger Lakes and stills, near enough to Auburn to go there occasionally for anything at the Seminary. Was at Hamilton last year for the 40th. About 15 of the class were back including Tom Miller & Wager. The old College is booming and certainly equals anything I have ever seen for Campus. Your 40th will soon be at hand and I hope that you may be able to return and see how different the present generation and surroundings contrast with ours in the roaring days of the 85 & 90 unclear. With studest?? regards and regrets at my failure to respond as Id like to have done, I am sincerely, Plato T. Jones

Springwater Waushara Co Wis, January 13th 1885 Dear friend Everett Yours of Decbr 29 came to hand in due time the 3rd of this month, I was down to Berlin at the time shut-up by snow. I know, I aut to settle up with you long before this. I do acknowledge my sin and I will leave it to as soon as I can take a couple of loads of Wheat to Market. June 16, 1921
My dear Classmate:
On May 16th the Class of 1891 of Union Theological Seminary has a private luncheon at the Aldine Club, Fifth Avenue and 23rd Street, New York City. Our Vice-president, J. Frederick Talcott, was in the chair and acted as toast-maker. It was by his courtesy and generosity that we were privileged to meet at this club, and the good-will and fellowship seemed complete. We surely recall the good old days in the old Seminary building at Park Avenue and 69th and 70th Streets, and the old familiar faces of our esteemed classmates came up before us, and their peculiar habits and traits were neither forgotten nor obliterated by the flight of time. 
We read extracts from letters where fellows were gracious enough to send them, and we recalled tenderly and lovingly those who "have fought the good fight of faith and have finished the course and won the crown." A shadow rested over us in the deaths in one year of Dan Overton, his sister, and his son. It is a strange Providence that took from life three such useful people and left Dan's poor old Mother at the age of 95. 
We had living words from the lips of Talcott, Mr. and Mrs. Elwood, Rohrabaugh, Losa, Houston, Cromie, Beebe, Fryling, Warren, Baldwin, Reinhart, French, Parsons, Kerr, Carter, and Kuebler. (Cole was with us part of the time.)
The best proof that a most pleasant time was experienced is evidenced by the fact that tho we gathered at 1 P.M. we were loath to part at 6 P.M. In the evening we shared the joys of the dinner at the Pennsylvania Hotel, and on the day following we were the guests of the Seminary.
Two resolutions were passed:
1. That we secure a letter from each fellow, obtaining as much personal history as possible from him for class purposes.
2. That we endeavor among ourselves, our Churches, or friends, to raise a fund for some gift (to be designated later) for our Seminary.
We send to each fellow our personal greetings.
Always sincerely, 
Secretary C. R. Keeber

To John Edward Everett different hand
Turin, Lewis Co. N.Y. Mar. 29. '80.
Dear Friend:
I never have rec'd a letter from you and, having gotten your address, thought I would send you a few lines and hope that you will answer and tell me how the world uses you.
I have been going to school most of the time this winter. Our teacher, Prof. L. D. Browne, is good, but he has a bountiful "gift of gab."
There are fifty on the roll up-stairs this term.
The boys often speak of you and the times we used to have at school.
I wish you were here this

winter, we would have glorious times.
I worked on a farm last summer, down in Jefferson Co. Went away from here the 10th of Apr. and didn't come home until the 12th of Dec.
I dont believe that I was "called" to "farm it."
Neil and I have been giving some entertainment this winter.
Chas Grell started for N.Y. City a few days ago.
I suppose that you have got thoroughly weaned from this place. Well! there isn't much to get weaned from, here; everything is quiet as usual. Except when the wind blows.
What do you intend to

do? Or, are you in the same boat that I am, waiting for time to disclose a field of labor. I heard that you were going to school this winter.
Chas. W. Collins and Frank Barnes talked of going to Whitestown to school but I dont know whether they will go or not.
Cade Jones started for Chicago afoot last Monday morning; he is a promising youth!
I acknowledge myself a poor letter writer, so please don't criticise.
Yours truly,
Byron A. Litchfield

Mr. & Mrs. J.E. Everett: -
Cannon Falls, Minn.
Dear Friends: -
We received your letter a few days ago and were not only surprised but delighted to get it. We had heard from the folks at home about your visit back in Smith Center. I expect that you were somewhat surprised at the changes in the old town. We were back there last summer and we noticed several changes in the town even though we had only been gone two years.
I was up in New York City the latter part of the last November and I thought of Roberts & Edward and even went so far as to try to look them up in the several telephone directories but there were so many with their names and so many different books to look in that I finally gave up. I was sure that Roberts was there and I had a "hunch" that Edward was there. If I am ever up there again I shall certainly make it a point to get in touch with the boys. I am not a good letter writer but I may do my self proud some of these 
cont

2.
days and write to Edward.
We do have an interesting little family. Lettye (my wife) is from north of Bellaire. We have Viriginia June 5 years Hilary Dennison II 3 1/2 year & Joyce Arlene 18 months. They are quite a hand full and manage to keep up busy. I thought I could send you a kodak picture of the children but cant seem to find one right now. Perhaps I will have a good one to send in a later letter.
Irene is here at present. She expects to leave for Mount Vernon N.Y. soon as Cliff is working there. She sends her best regards.
If you folks are ever in Washington we want you to get in touch with us. We only live a little way across the Patomac and would be glad to drive in and get you and to show you some of the sights. At present Washington is all "a-flurry" over the inauguration. It will be the first spree of that kind we have ever seen.
I have always been sorry that I dident accept Edward's and Margaret's invitation to visit you folks when you were in Overbrook. We all hope that everything is going well with you and that we may get together some time for a nice long visit.
Yours sincerely
Hilary D Martin.

ATTORNEY AT LAW,
PAOLA, KANSAS.
October 18, 1902.
J.E.Everett Esq.,
Topeka, Kansas.
"In re" Everett vs. Everett.
Dear Sir: --

 I have your favor of the 17th inst. and note contents. In reply say that it will be necessary to have the original Mortgages here with the Notes held by M.H.Everett. The rules of the Court require that the originals be filed when judgment is taken. I could prepare the pleadings on copies but the records do not show a copy of the notes; hence it will be necessary even to prepare the papers to have the original before me.
 As to the matter of fees there are two Mortgages and the labor in connection with this branch of the case will be just the same as if they were prosecuted as separate actions of foreclosure, and the minimum fee in such cases would be $25. for each case, but inasmuch as I represent you in the partition suit and you have to pay the fee on this branch of the case, I will attend to the collection of both Mortgages for one fee of $25. That would be $12.50 for each case. There will be a saving of about $15 in costs if this course is adopted. I could enter an appearance for the defendant M.H.Everett and save cost of publication of summons. The Attorney's fee of lien holders in partition suits is not fixed by the Court. The only Attorney's fee apportioned by the Court is for services rendered in the partition proceeding. 
 If you will procure the original papers, that is the notes and mortgages held by M.H.Everett I will see that her interests are protected and that her liens are paid out of the proceeds of the sale of the property. 
Respectfully, J.E. Maxwell

J.E. Maxwell, Esqr.  Paola, Kansas.
Dear Sir: -- In your letter of Wednesday you say "I have today received a letter from J.E. Everett, in which he authorizes me to confer with you and correct any errors that may appear on the face of the record in the Probate Court."  Does this include the failure to give the estate credit for interest on the funds lying in his hands? - If not the most important point in my proposition has been overlooked, as the errors apparent upon the face of the accounts, - aside from the administrator's charges - involve only small amounts, as in the matter of tax receipts, and that of sale bills, which were noticed in our conversation in your office. 

 If this matter is included, we should have Mr. Everett's statement of the approximate time of his collection of the rents, and also of his payment for the monument, for which he has not taken credit until the 5th account, though he probably pain for it long before.    You will doubtless remember my suggestion that in this case, in view of his irregular bookkeeping it would seem proper to reverse the usual rule and construe in his favor all reasonable doubts- 
 By reason of some business changes in progress, I

will not be able to do any work in the case until the latter part of next week, and any statement of objections that I could make without the data above mentioned, would necessarily be based upon assumed dates of collection and payment, and would be subject to correction when the true dates are disclosed. 

 To avoid misunderstanding I will put in writing the proposition verbally made in our office --- If the Administrator will correct the errors shown upon the face of his accounts as filed, and will also give the estate credit for interest at 7% upon all funds belonging to the estate for the time that same was or should have been in his hands, then I will suffer his claims for services and expenses, appearing in his accounts filed prior to Nov. 20" 1902 to pass without objection; said amounts so claimed to be in full payment of all services rendered or to be rendered as such Administrator or otherwise, in connection with said estate. 

Yours
John J. Werninger

Respectfully,
J.E. Maxwell

Dear Sir:--
I have your favors of the 8th and 9th. I will forward your statement of account to Mr. Werninger, and will report to you as soon as I hear from here.
I notice that you do not desire to bid more than $4500. for the property; I also note that you are not likely to be here on the 23rd inst. It will not be necessary for you to be here on that day, but that will take the final closing up of this estate over to February, provided you are the purchaser of the property. In case any other person than yourself is the purchaser we could have the sale confirmed at an adjourned day of the present term, towards the end of December. 

 I understand that if you are the purchaser it will be necessary for you to borrow $2500. and of course in order to borrow the money, you would have to give Mortgage on the property, to secure it, and if you are out if the state, the Mortgage could not be executed after the sale and returned here in time to have the sale confirmed. When you make up your mind definitely as to whether you will be here or not on the 23rd, advise me so that I can arrange the case as may be necessary. 

Respectfully,
J.E. Maxwell

Kansas City, Mo. Jan. 25, 1913
Rev. J. E. Everett, 

  Smith Center, Kansas.

Dear Mr. Everett: 

  Your letter of the 22nd inst., received, and also book was received on the same mail. I have read some of the "Quillings" and like them very well, as does also Mrs. McClure from what she has read of them.
  In answer to the inquiry in regard to my Mother, will state that she died about three years ago at Tacoma, Washington. She is buried in a very beautiful cemetery where the grass keeps green all the year around. Last June Mrs. McClure and I took a trip out there to see all the folk, and I laid some flowers on her grave. 
  Haddie and Lizzie live at Tacoma and are doing very well. You remember that Haddie was married and lost her husband. She has a boy about 14 years old. Lizzie is still single and keeps house for them. They like that country very much. I have two other sisters up on Puget Sound which makes the most of the family up there in touch with each other. Mrs. McClure thinks that the happiest days we have spent in our married life were in Kiowa, and

- 2 -
the most particularly happiest years were the two that we spent on the claim. We certainly did enjoy the going back and forth from town, and having everything so nicely arranged for us. While we have reached out and have more of the comforts of life, and have seen a great deal of life since that time, yet after all we have not enjoyed anything more than our pleasant and happy Kiowa days, where our Son was born and where we have so many friends now. We left Kiowa in the spring of 1896, going to Caldwell, Kansas, and we left there in the spring of 1899 coming to Kansas City. I enclose a statement showing the kind of business and its extent that I now engage in. As you know, Major Drumm is an old man and the principal part of the business is now on my shoulders. We had a very prosperous year in 1912, and with continued good prospects for 1913. 
Mrs. McClure and I were very glad indeed to learn of your family and their progress. I would be glad to have Howard call on my, if not at the house, sometime at the office. I happen to be President of the Hoof & Horn Club the social organization of the commission men here at the Yards, and would like to have Howard come down and take luncheon with me at the Club some day and renew our acquaintance. I remember him very well and especially the time that he fell off of the horse and got hurt.
Mrs. McClure's health is not very good. She has the same old trouble with headaches that she had in Kiowa. This last summer the Doctor put her on a milk diet and she gained considerably in flesh although I can't see that her general health is much better. 
With kindest regards both for myself and wife to you and your family, I am with best wishes
Sincerely yours,
M.L. McClure

Smith Center Kansas November 1st 1920. 
Mr. and Mrs. Everett, 
My Dear Friends: 
I received letter with character sketch of Mr. McDowell and think you must have been very observing and your memory exceptionally good to give such a correct discription of his manners and habits after so long a time. Have read it at our family gatherings (Mrs. Coolidge included) and of course shed a few tears "In memorium" all join

in thanking you for kindly remembering us. I am at home again after a trip into nebraska and a visit at Ottawa where my only brother lives, while there I looked you up on the map, thinking I might possible call on you on my way home but did not see any way clear to do so. I did not even stop in Topeka Maude and Theodore live at North Platte Nebr about one hundred miles north and the same distance west of here. They live in an Apartment

for which they pay $45. per month. It takes all one can earn now to make ends meet. Leila is in school and Sunday school, There is no Cong. church there so they will join the Presbyterian. 

 Jamie and David are well and getting alng nicely. Mrs. Everett, I suppose you are home after your long absence during the hot weather. I hope you are well and feeling rested after your vacation. there seems to be lots of pep in the cold air this

bright morning after a 24 hours rain. I have a girl going to school, plenty of coal and everything to make me comfortable  As for clothes - nothing new in this house until prices come down. Civic League is still alive we have a room in the new court house Mrs. Shoemaker is sec'y is a good help. Mrs Ike Grahim is here with Kitty in the Harwood house - The Fortnightly meets with her next time. Mrs. Kate Relihau's health is not good at all. Mrs. Hesters house is for sale. She will live with her son Thomas.

2 
Tomorrow is Election What will the Out-come be?
The Kingsburys are in California for the winter the Bert Travis family have moved there bought and built in Long Beach. Dr. Frank Relihens are about to move into their new house just west of Dr. W.'s Home. Art and Hader? are already in theirs and Teds is just east of Mrs. Hatties not yet completed, Roger Coolidge and Mr. Alfond live, have homes on the

old Defembeau? place all there young people are getting along fine. Mildred Alford is teaching. 

 The north part of town is being built up. I wish you people would motr up some time and look Smith Center over, you would hardly recognize some parts of the city. 
  Schuyler Slaters? mother is very poorly at this time. By the way Schuylers Orchard and nursery grounds are really beautiful especially in Spring and summer when

in bloom and in fruit time. Mr. and Mrs. Hill are alone now Joel their youngest is at the university of Iowa he is a fine fellow. has one year more there 

  I suppose Mary is the only one you have with you, when you have time write and tell me about your visit East and how each member of your family is prospering. 

Very Sincerely your Friend Condelia A. McDowell.

Home Parish N.Y.
   July 20th 1885

My Dear Edd

  Having some leisure it occured to me to write you and try the constancy of your brotherly affection.    However, I think this would bring an answer from you anyway, for ere I close I shall touch upon a theme in which you are much interested and ask you to give me a candid, Serene An'a thoughfull reply.

Well, I've been laboring long and hard to-day 
Turning and pitching the "sweet scented" hay
While my hands are blistered and fingers sore
And I've been vaguely asking if my name's More.
You see, it was late, to begin with, when I came home
Father had been sick and had very little done
There was the corn to hoe and the weather's been bad
With no one to work but my-self and dad

  And so it's gone slow

But we've done our best, we've worked when we could
We've hoed, we've "hayed it, we've cut up wood,

But as I sit here now with my hands all sore 
I am vaguely inquiring if my name's More.
That More, I mean, who was in college - you know 
Who took life so easy, worked little, went slow 
Had the comforts of life, some of its luxuries too, 
Studdied some, crammed some "cribbed" enough to "get through" yet, 
Who stayed at Commencement, took it all in, 
Flirted with a young lady and got took in?
Went back "on the hill" after a whole week's excess
Entertained a class mate - a fellow traveler in distress

  Had talked it all over,

That is the one, Ah! you know him I see
Prehaps you were with him, but is that he
Who sits here now with his hands all sore?
Is that the same fellow, is is name More?
You would hardly believe it - so great the change
His face all sun-burnt, so ragged, so strange
But these ragged clothes, these hands that are sore
Belong to the same fellow, belong to that More

   And I am he

Well, Ive got now where I know positively who I am, perhaps I may write intelligently.

Since I parted with you I've been wondering what your experience was in Utica before going home. First, how did you find Rich?? I havent imagined but that he is Delta Upsilon sure enough but what did he think of us while here I was sorry we did not give him more attention. You probably talked with him what did you make out?
 Second, what has been the development with Miss Irene? You saw her, of course, but did you see her alone?  Those girls are a quandry to me, and yet I think very well of them indeed. I think I never met a lady of whom I could not form an opinion more easily than of Miss Hill. I have only an impression and that is favorable, but not definate. (you know our oppinions are "co" but private)
 The are intelligent and pleasant company and I hope we may retain them as real friends. Will the issues in your case prevent it? I imagined Miss Wood would have favored

correspondence, but what I had gleaned of your position advised me not to suggest it. I would like to have corresponded but if it were to convey the idea that I mean "biz" I thought it would be best to forbear. Well give me developements and your oppinions.

 As you may have imagined before this - we have been haying and, knowing your intense appreciation of the poetic part of farming I have often imagined you in some fense? corner, - resting? the haying through at a great rate. 
 I have taken enough rest so far to read Curiosity Shop, one vol. Longfellow and Holland and am wishing now for some more books by the same authors. 
I am anticipating the return to college and think we can make it a pleasant and a profitable year.     Answer me soon with several folios and much news

With kindest wishes
Warren D.? More

 We rode by perfumed fields in the sunlight and the twilight, we strolled over beautiful glades and watched the sunset in the lake --- we sang in a cozy parlor; but, the pleasures of a twilight drive, the beauties of a summer's sun, falling beneath the billowy Ontario and the enchantment of an evening song, are but instruments in bringing out in clearer richer colors, the many beauties that may

Mexico Academy.
Mexico, N.Y., Feb. 17 1889
My Dear John:
It is needless to say I was surprised to receive your ready response nor do I deny the imputation -- my letter or rather note, was  a "feeler". From the quick reply, I judge you are the same Edd -- ever ready to resent an insincerity; and shall therefore expect no reply to what I shall endeavor to make this letter -- an honest expression of friendship and of brotherhood.
I was much pleased

with your newsy letter. And glad to know you are at work under circumstances that you enjoy. I hear from Prof. H.R. Parker? occasionally and have been pleased to learn through him that you and Chester as well are doing good work. You did not say what your tutoring is but I should think you would find the combined dates of teacher

and student somewhat burdensome. Undoubtedly the smiles, sunshine and cheerful atmosphere that must necessarily surround a female seminary lighten the burdens and otherwise releive the monotonous routine of seminary work. I believe the burdensome duties of teaching find their full antedote in this contact, daily and hourly, with bright, pure, young womanhood and manhood.
Of course in a school like Mexico Academy the students are not all unclear

the majority of that class but a goodly number of them are, and its before this class that the teacher finds satisfaction for his labors. We have a full school now and had last term as well. The attendance has been fully up to my expectations and the work quite as propsperous. Don't think I shall get quite a thousand dollars from the year's work but shall be

satisfied with the result I think. Have an excellent and pleasant preceptress and also an excellent assistant in Prof. Banister. War room to gather here in the Academy (i.e. Banister and I) very much like college days in the rooms on the Hill. Have pleasant rooms -- Headquarters and general rendesvous for all D.U.'s in this part of the state. Call on us; we will do our best to entertain Banister sits here opposite me now writing to "his girl" -- a regular routine three times

a week. Im not doing the same thing now. For I have recently finished my Sunday epistle. In regard to your query, I take it you ask out of something more than mere curiosity and do not hesitate to answer frankly. The time of our marriage is not fixed. I would like it to be next summer, but presume it will not be best for me before a year from that time. This bit of confidence is for

yourself please. When the time comes if I am so fortunate as to have your address you may consider yourself unfortunate.
Fred Waite was down the first part of the term and stayed here Saturday with me. He is not at all satisfied with Washington and thought he would not go back. Had a letter from Pendrick today. He asked for your address. Squires, Cole, Emery, Bradley and Mitchell are laboring at Auburn. I expect to visit here

at the close of the term; that is, after I have first visited Utica I spent Thanksgiving with the boys and had a very pleasant time.
Am not decided yet what I shall do next year. Would like to go immediately to the seminary and rather think I shall, but may wait for a year yet. Do you know Deacon Colson's address? I would like to learn something of Princeton.
Give my regards to

Henry and Chester. Is Henry making a business of tutoring? I heard from Henry a short time ago.
Shall be glad to hear from you Edd., as you find leisure for writing and expect always to hear of your successful labor.
With every brother feeling, yours still
Deacon

UNIVERSITY OF SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA
UNIVERSITY PARK
LOS ANGELES
July 1934
Dear Mr Everett:
Certainly glad to hear from you. Much news and mighty interesting. Hoped to be able by stirring around a bit to get some news on the weighty problem of the right job for the right man, at the right time. School, teaching, business, travel, higher degree, and ripe and ready for a better teaching job. What a combination, but everyone in the teaching field out here is hanging on to their job with all the teeth they have left. And schools are not expanding. And so.....I regret to report that at present.....but I will not forget.
As to other things we have a little Kiowa of our own out here and meet once a month. George Wells and wife, two daughters, two sons, two sons-inlaw, two daughters-in-law, and by the last count nine grandchildren, or is it ten or eleven. Marston Wells died two years ago, and Mrs McMahan four years ago when on a visit to us.
Mrs Marston Wells is still with us, and wrote marvelous poetical minutes for the Kiowa club until two years ago. And now Ida Nay shines as poetical recorder of the deeds and doings of the said club. Her father is still alive, and still a great checker player. Her sister Nellie Nay Morrill lives in Pasadena and has a mighty nice married daughter.
Harry Matthews died but his wife May and a couple of sons and daughters and theirs add to the list.
Stella Hockenberry Wilson (Mrs Tommy) has a marvelous daughter Gladys (Mrs Robert Burgess) and they have a college girl (Mary Bob) and three sons. Abner Wilson died a year ago, but his wife and two sons and two daughters are still with us, all married. Uncle Jack Crewdson, after a long illness died just the other day.
The Strothers family adds about eight to our gatherings, and Mrs Milton Wells (Willa Patton) and married daughter Jean. Milt lives up in the mountains. They got a divorce.
Who else? Gertrude Cattell and her two boys went back to Denver last year but could not escape as a big bad bold California man went after her and married her. Hope he'll bring her back.
Chas Skilling (or was he after your date, anyway he was Ada's brother) is an old bach living in Walnut Park, a suburb.
Mrs Laughman comes out every year.
Just had a wire from Mary McMahan that Dorsey Singleton died day before yesterday. (Wednesday) He had been in poor health and his mind was affected. A blessing that he found release.
Dora is still going strong and having a good time with her church work and Faculty Wives Club (Treasurer, or Secretary from time to time) and the Town and Gown Club, and bossing her son John age 26, weight 201, and me,...age not mentioned, weight now down to 165, bath room weight, after having had a street weight for some years of 200.

John took his bachelors degree here four years ago, went to New York for Macy's Executive Training course (two years), came back and took his masters degree in Economics, and has been doing various things this year along research lines. Hope to send him to Germany for a year for his Ph.D., when finances and Germany improve.
Oh yes. Addie Rumsey George, husband and daughter Margaret live in Escondido. We get a whale of a chicken dinner by going down there once a year. Margaret graduates this year from San Diego State Normal and is headed for library work.
Clate Herr lives in Palo Alto, and his two married daughters near by. Ada, who is still with Southwestern at Winfiled was out here on a sabbatical last year, guess it was two years.
Of my old high school class, Stella Hockenberry lives at Long Beach, Addie Rumsey in Escondido, Clate Herr in Palo Alto, and since being here I have met Emma Jones, visiting from Kingman Kansas, and Mary McSherry Gaskill visiting from Alva Oklahoma. Only Linc Herr now associate justice of Okla Supreme Court, and Albert Rumsey still at Kiowa have insisted remaining permanently around the old stamping ground.
Be good to yourselves. If I get time when I pass through Chicago I'd like to call on Zaidee if you would send me her address or have her come down town for lunch. I have most flattering memories of her as well as of you and Mrs Everett. I often think of you not only as the man who gave me my final high school exam in Greek, and as teacher who stepped in the high school breach and filled it like Horatio at the Bridge, but as the first broad minded, sane, tolerant, preacher with whom I ever came in contact.
My best, our best, to you and yours,
WD Moriarty

318 West 135th St.
Oct. 26th 1890.
Dear Jack --
Marie says come back and she will have you up to supper -- I went down to Far Rockaway last week Tuesday. Is asking all that is necessary? Because if it is consider yourself asked and send me unclear to me as quickly as possible. Were you needed in S.S. this afternoon? Well I should say we were most decidedly Dr. Terry was expected to be there as

this is Eugene's Sunday off but Dr. T. did not appear & no other man only the "Infant Crosby" who came & asked me to open the school but I objected, I did it the first Sunday & did not propose to again -- So Edward C. opened the school with Singing & closed it with Singing but did not offer even "The Lord's Prayer" -- I do wish you had been there -- but what a useful mill.
I wrote to you very Soon after receiving your letter in Sept.

3

sending it to Ossawatomie with the request to "forward if necessary" but I have not heard from you since -- Why? I want to know all about your new field as particularly as you wrote me about Sedan & Waneta -- I do hope you are enjoying your work more & more all the time. You would smile to see what a woman of business I am & in so many different directions. I am to be paid, I believe for the work I do in & for the S.S. & perhaps have charge of the Ind. School -- I have a class

in Kinder garten Sewing at Mrs. Roberts School every Friday from 1-2 -- I am one of the consignor's at the Woman's Exchange taking every Friday morning Salad & Maynuaised eggs -- as my one dish if they sell I am paid if not I lose -- of course it is a trial, so far do not know whether I am successful or not. I do some sewing & some shopping I have been obliged to give up charging commission & I will send you one of my new circulars & more if you can dispose of them, I would like these sent wherever

5 

the others were last year because if charging Commission presented any one from sending these the new plan might induce these. I am still able to live but will not be long unless I get some more classes or a great deal more shopping -- but I try to think all is coming out well I have never been stranded & guess I will not be now.
I left mother at Far Rockaway Thursday afternoon late where I came up in order? to make ready & take things to the Mercan'l Exchange & then as I had to be here today I concluded

not to return until early tomorrow A.M -  Mother is quite contented there with that dear baby Ida is going on East to Boston etc - I am doing some work for her in order to facilitate her departure & to take my board here & make some money there. Next week I am going to sew a couple of days for Clara I went out there yesterday for a few hours - Nill is not at all well he has unclear worked? & has what the doctor calls "Mental Depression" & advises his going away - I hope he can, he

goes to business every day & had begun taking Russian baths & a tonic he is already improving but it may be very slow - & of course Clara is much distressed. Mr. Eaton has reached San Diego & is delighted with the place & has improved. - 
Agnes Meany spent Tuesday night & part of Wednesday at Silas' & he did enjoy seeing her again, she is delighted to get back to N.Y. did not like the west at all, but she is very thankful she went this Summer & saw her dear mother once more -

Surely you do not mean to stop writing because you have decided to stay west? No indeed - Two weeks ago tonight my cousin Mattie Midbury that was Mattie Symunds that is took tea with us they were on their wedding trip & seemed (of course) very happy - Marie was away so I got tea & entertained them as if in my own house - Marie spent several days in, do excuse it, Flemington with her brother & sister-in-law, so I was decidedly busy.
Geo. Murray is still faithful & Mr. L. is going to hunt up the rest of your once

9
large class.
Two weeks ago today Mr. Hastings came & taught, he spoke of you & of missing you at the Seminary. Do you hear from Mr. Roger? I find Miss Maggie D? usually? does when away from home, & he continues to call - 
I must to bed as I must rise early in order to get down to F.R. for a day's work, I will probably stay there until Thursday afternoon.
I tried to get the letter you sent to F.R. & that failed to reach me but it was sent to the "Dead Letter Office" & there destroyed. you must have failed to put it in Ida's care & so it has sent to Washington after a certain length of time. I a very sorry &

particularly so as it contained the Whys & Wherefores of your decision to stay West - Will you write it here again & that soon?
With affection 

Yours faithfully - 
  Edith Ramsey

P.S.
One of the terrible? thoughts I wanted to write about was the teasers? to which I referred in one of my other letters - I have two pair of winter ones & I think you could wear them & if you want them  I should so like to have you the unclear to have them & then tho I have a good big & quite heavy ulster and also a heavy puita? velvet, which are unclear prefer you are more than welcome to if you are

willing to pay the Express & will tell me where and how best to send them you will give both mother & myself much pleasure - 
I am back in Far Rockaway now & Eugene says direct this to Sedan - so I will - Mamma has contended well during my absence & more than happy to get me back - Mr Nill remains here not longer than Thursday - 
Do write very soon - 
As ever
Edith

318 West 135th St.

April 18th/91
Dear Jack -

You have a great Comfort in your sympathy a year ago today when my fine dear mother had left this world & us -- God bless you - I wish you could look in upon us to night Confusion has plagued for several days, packing has been going on, the dining-

room has unclear six barrels in it all packed ready to go in the van next Friday morning. I have gotten out & put in use my china & today I went after my silver & a week from today my uncle keeping unclear  & I do hope & expect to enjoy it. It is so nice to see some of the old things once more & to put them into use -- I am to teach or I would write more to night I am delighted unclear Rossiter is in

correspondence with you. May real substantial good come out of it

  April 27th

I began time keeping Sat. Such a place as that has been  So much going on & Marie got off on Sat. I have ever & ever so much to do yet & will write a letter when I can - I want to get this off this morning because I have a letter to enclose which I took charge of to send to her? at Mr. Lentillena? next?

so busy & so upset running? to the Country  I had a letter started to you the letter came in next the L_ several words unclear
I took the liberty of reading? it feeling quite sure you would be willing -- it is a really good letter & so gratifying I know you will be please, he wrote Eugene a very good letter also. Do write soon again I am so anxious to hear more of the offer from Dr. Rossiter's Second?

I have much to write you

when I can take the time. Mr. [Leutillim?]] wished me to remember him to you very friendly & say he had a letter commenced to you & had had some time he has been sick & is not well unclear  Ida is not well the Baby is thirsting  Eugine said he would send me a picture sometime. You are coming East are you not? I must stop breakfast dishes are waiting to be washed. 

 Yours faithfully
 Edith Ramsey

Mama is real well again.

Dear Morris. If John Ed is not there or cannot will you please attend to this E.R.W.
Flint Creek N.Y. Feb 10th 1888
Dear John Ed.
Your letter written on Sat. night received. Enclosed please find a note for 38.00 to the College for my term bill last term. You probably comprehend it all. Through some low-lived conniving of Rent? and Borst I was forced to give my note last term for 60 days on $38.00 and it falls due next monday, I think it is. Will you be kind enough to act as my attorney and see the business straightened out. You will have to present the enclosed note to Borst for endorsement and then the Bankers will accept it, and be sure to get the old note and keep it for me. If there is any thing to pay I will make it all right with you when I get back. But before you present this enclosed note to Borst ask him if the note I gave the latter part of last term went to the Bank or not. If it has not then tell him that I have made arraingments to give my note for the whole payable one year after graduation. Don't forget this will you please. Avoid a protest by all means. I will be back in about two weeks Yours Fraternally
E R Whitney

Elo
July 16 - 1883
Dear Mr. Everett
I am afraid by this time that you think that I am very ungrateful for not writing before to let you know I received the book alright and I thank you ever and ever so much for it I think it is very handsome I did not ever expect to get such a nice presant but hope I can return the kindness some time. I have read it through and found it very interesting. my school was out last Friday. we were lonesome after you went away. the girls thought it was to bad to have you leave before

you hardly got acquainted but I suppose you thought sooner the better to be out of such a tough crowd. Jennie wants to know if you have told the young ladies east how Wisconsin girls make a mash [with eggs] Papa sent you a letter last week with some money in it did you get it we often look and laugh at the marks you and Charlie left on the ceiling Well Papa and Mama are going to Picketts so I have a chance to send these the girls send's there best Sunday go to meeting regards and also myself 
Charlie wants you to come back here to help him take care of these girls and want to know if you made as good a mash on your way back as you did here that means that egg of course.

Well well I guess that I have made enough blots and blunders so I will stop for fear you will get tired of a little girls scribbling so I will stop good by
this from
Ida C Williams
Elo
Wis

The DU house being built (largely by Grif) on the campus is in a commanding position. The "old" house is begging on the market. An offer of $3000 for it has been made, by Prof  Saunders.
I was greatly impressed with the college comforts and general prosperity of the college, notwithstanding the pusinallimous (revised spelling) of the president and some of the faculty. 
Hamilton is plainly not in touch with the strong educational trend of today. On the contrary, it has great opportunities to become the leading college of the East, but spurns them, with hauteur. It imitates the proud old sea captain who preferred to become a hero and sink with his time honored vessel, instead of adopting modern methods of live saving. There are 100 Ham. Coll. grads holding college or Supts positions in the educational world able to put Ham. Coll. where she belongs. Well, old boy, sorry to bore you. Glad to hear from you
With best wishes Eli

1312 State St.,
Emporia, Kans.
April 11, 1923.
Dear Mr. and Mrs. Everett:
Since I received such a nice interesting letter from Mr. Everett, I tho't I'd better show my appreciation by answering it. You might like to get some 'news.'
I'm in the dear old town of Emporia gaining some knowledge, at least trying to. The colleges in Minnesota are a little too far away for me.
Is Mary home yet? I heard she was rather homesick. She left Overbrook before people were really aware

of her going. I didn't stay much longer than she did. I suppose the poor old town is lonesome without us.
I have a real nice place to stay. The lady lets us use her things and is very kind. There is a grown girl and a boy about 10 or 12 years old. He has some of his friends here tonite, and actually they're making the most noise Ive heard for some time - since school has been out. They're about to go through the floor.
I was rather glad when school closed. The roads were bad so there wasn't a very large crowd, but we had a dandy time.
I can't tell you much about Overbook. The C.E. didn't get to have their usual sunrise breakfast. We tho't it would be too cold, so early in the morning.
Jennie and Joe were up home Easter. Everyone wanted to have Anna Mae at the same time. But she's getting so she has something to say about things, too; she knows her mother and seems to think

quite a bit of her. That was the first time they had been home for several weeks, because Mother and Dad had been having the Flu. Mother, I guess isn't getting better very fast, from what I hear; but Dad is alrite again.
I have a real nice roommate, a girl from Soldier, Kans. I tho't I was lucky to get one the very first day. My aunt came down with me for company. She stayed from Mon. till Fri.
I'll be glad to hear from you any time. Letters seem pretty good to me now.
Sincerely
Anna P.K.

Each Alumnus is requested to send to the Secretary not later than December 15 a quotation from Shakespeare in answer to any or all of the following questions.
