Kalamazoo Mich July 18th 1916
My Dear JE

Your letter of sunday came today. I was so lonesome and hot sunday the hottest here in twenty years. I nearly gave out. It seemed a little cool yesterday yet one mare died of the heat. Today it is a very little cooler just a light breeze. I got up before time and did the washing and I had the room all cleaned up by mm. I am however all tired out and ought not to

have done it but there seems no other way. I think it would have cost me at the lowest estimate $200. I have to do the marking for the beds so you see I am doing regular housework. Now tomorrow it is brim with oldfashionend busy. I feel that we certainly must get located at once. This is far from being home with all the old cracked dishes and old things that ought to be in the garrett. It is the same in all the places. I fail to see your brand of romance in this situation There may be a little here and there along lifes way but it come in spots but I cant see any now. You may think I am clever but I think I can detect romance now any other where I meet it. Get everything soon and get us together. I have not room here for Margeret so you see if I am here in these rooms when she comes we will have to get another room here or elsewhere. I dont suppose my proposition about going to

together it would be easier to wait and will not be any more costly in the end. Edw is stretching his imagination when he writes you about my fifteen minute stunts. I have to keep his desires down or I would be bankrupt. Oh dear I just let Mery ask Mrs. Jones if she had something she could let her have for a dish rag & she said no that she had not any for herself. I am nearly to the end of my string Get someone to work up

the Remsen project. Surely we can go on in a few more weeks.
I dont want the children to go down to the library this PM but hey seem to want to have some outlet but it is so very warm. The children are both growing fast and were older in many ways than a few months ago.
Tell Aunt Mery we hope she is standing this warm spell fairly well. The children had a letter from Roberts yesterday with a dollar bill to be shared between them. It was a good letter for them. I am hoping every letter will bring us good news. 
I want to be by ourselves for I do hate to have anyone feel sorry for me and that is the way the Derlet? folk feel. I cannot get the kind of rooms they could get dont misunderstand me they are just as nice to me but you can feel things. I want my

care for Aunt Mary. The Children are so big now that I dont think she would mind them It was Miss Naujway? that made the trouble about Mary. This must close and we must be together as soon as we can Only about 7 weeks until time for school. Get after the NY men and see if they cant get you something now when you go back there. I dont take any stock in Boston - the Dr Carval? plan semekers?. If we could have our home and family

own place.
Let me hear when there is any thing. It is so hot up here I may not write much for a whil.
Lovingly,
your wife
Helen Everett

Kalamazoo Mich July 31, 1916
My Dear Folks. 

 This is another day of the dreadful heat. It is alarming it is lasting so long. Nine prostrations Saturday here. Stores closed at two PM. Work is stopped in the streets and some places just closed until there is a let up. We are feeling all played out & hope for a change every day. I think I never felt the heat any worse it is so humid & sultry. Wm had prostration for a day and is hardly able to pull along. Bertha played out yester-

2 

day and they are going to get her to the lake today if she will go. Mr. Hathaway is with them. There is not anything to write form here. We are trying to be as quiet as possible but we can hardly stand the heat. some day we just cont^e? at our work up here but still we are alright. We are glad you are not suffering much with the heat. The weather man says no change for at least 48 hrs. here. It is near nine oclock and Mery is asleep on the floor. She put in a bad time of it all night. Edw is taking a bath. We have not had break-

3 

fast yet. We will get down on the porch in a little while. I wonder if you were at Millers Place yesterday you did not say anything about it. Perhaps you will hear from Sharon after yesterday. I hope so. What does Dr. Shelton say in regard to anything opening soon in NY. I know you will enjoy your trip Roberts will? wish you had a longer vacation? time. We have heard nothing from Margaret all week. 

Edw will send something in this so I will not write any more now. Will you go to Remsen if nothing opens for Aug. Surely

something will however I think they will. 

Lovingly your wife & mother.
 Helen Everett

602. Elm

Kalamazoo Mich Aug 4th, 1916
Dear JE

 Your letter to Mery came today and you seem to be a little discouraged. I am sure I dont know what is the offer. I suppose there will be little doing during this month. If the wait is to be long it would be better if we could be together as a family. Could you fix things in Remsen so you could supply until you got a permanent pulpit? I think somehow you will hear soon from some one. I dont suppose you are in touch with Brehm. Are you? Now last night Wm came after me and took me to see some rooms near them and I took them for a month or I will pay for a month. These are $23.00 per month. This is dreadful but unclear not Bertha will come to see me in our rooms here. Wm is charged with father and I dont want him to worry over us here. These rooms are not really

desirable here and would have to have another for Margeret really. Now we I hope can go on to you at the end of the month Sept 6th. It will be as cheap to get a home and have our own things I think as it will to pay furnished room. If by this time you are not settled unclear Make the settle permanently but have to wait until it will be better I think the do this way. There is not any use to get blue but hope now things will move. I will get along without any more money untill the end of the month. I suppose Margeret will be coming soon. I wrote her telling her to stay in KC and then I got the letter I sent you and then I told her to come for I am afraid she is working to hard. unclear said you had had no letter from

us the day you wrote. page torn off
sent one every day. When we dint torn off
off in the AM we give it til the next man at 4 PM and I suppose you get it then in the evening. I did a big washing this AM and I am certainly tired all out. I wanted to leave the things here clean and then our own things made an endless wash. Now I am boing to feel that we will come on in Sept and think things will shape themselves somehow. Perhaps we will hear yet today that something has opened up, there is not any phone here and when I get to the other place I will try and call up the HS Supt or the clerk of school board or somebody and try and settle Edw about school. He wants to go to the Normal but we had better get them east and start them there if possible. Edw is restless and it is hard to settle them both. I think I must have a case of brain fag for I certainly have to settle thing ab? I dont know how many times a day. We had a thunder shower last night but today it is sultry and we do not get good air up here. I have

to straighten up now. I quit unclear the bed for a while had lunch so I must wipe up the kitchen unclear now. I wish you would both think seriously about so coming on. We would not have to unpack all our goods. I dont know what is best but think we better be settled soon. 

 Lovingly Helen.

Kalamazoo Mich Aug. 4, 1916.
My Dear JE.
Here we are again the second letter today. We are in our new room and it certainly seems good to be down where we can get fresh air.
Aunt Bertha called and said that they were feeling fine now and that they did not see how we lived in the other place. I pd a month rent and will be alright here for the month. I hope as I said in my letter this AM that we can go on by that time I think the school problem will work out alright here. Margeret is to be in Durand today. I was dreadfully homesick and all in this AM but am feeling more hopeful now about things. Perhaps you will yet get something for Sunday but will just have to wait until things open up. The children now have lotta? to stay with them and play and they go over there and things seem more like

like home? Lotta? is here now and are having a good time playing flinch? I know we cannot pay this rent and will have to make some change at the end of the month. This place makes me think of the Aunties home. Miss Cerle is a modern woman and clerks in her brothers book store. There were six in the house here at one time and only one remains the others are all gone. Mrs. Parkard died just a few weeks ago and I have her part of the house. I think Mrs. P owned the place and the heirs are letting the Aunt remain in the house to look after the renting of the place. We are all alone during the day. There is a room or so up stairs to rent and will have others then in the home. Perhaps later on the day I will get a letter from you I will have to send over the Elm for the mail when Lotta goes home

I think I overworked yesterday for I can hardly get anything to eat or anything else. Let me hear often and hang on until things come. I dont want to leave Roberts now if we can help it but can not wait very long unless we can straighten thing onto about school &c. I am just going to do nothing about it and if we have to just start there in and fight it out then. I am sorry I wrote you this AM when I was so blue. I have money to last me this month so dont worry about that. It is very warm again today. I hope Roberts will not have to give up his vacation trip. I must dress and go out and find something to eat for over Sunday.
lovingly your wife
Helen Everett
524 W Cedar St.

Kalamazoo Mich May 7th 1916
My Dear Folks
Nothing particular to write only to let you hear from us. There was a bad storm here last night and it is a little cooler today but still very warm. Mary got a letter today from one of her dear 
transcriber's note: Helen Glazier Everett had a brother William, presumably she lifted some of his office paper for this letter.

-2-

Durand friends and she said we had seen her Marys sister go by with Mr. Bauman. So Margaret is there. I think she might let us hear from her. I dont know what I have been doing all summer if I have not been faceing facts or what I am doing now but just that very thing. If tuition has to be paid it will be $60 for each but I think Wm is alright where he

3
letterhead op. cit.
days that is the tuition for nonresidents but I am going to go on the fact that this is my home if I have any, I think perhaps by the time this month is up you will have something to do. I said I could manage this month and we must some

4
how leave the insurance alone. If we get it of some one else if we have to do so, it will get payed back but it never will the other way. The expence of the school books here I thought we might save if we went on to NY but then you dont know the least thing about where we will be. I dont know what

5

letterhead op. cit.
to do one minute or the other. I cant tell this woman? here what I want she would like to have us stay but has to make her plans I will just have to tell her I wil get out if she finds someone to take these rooms.

6 

as I can not pay the price unless Edw could take care of the furnace and that will be at least the first of Oct. I cant imagine how we stood the Elm St. rooms now that we are down stairs. We are not sorry we got out as our health counts something. Have you taken $400 besides the first? 75 for Diana from the unclear?

7 

letterhead op. cit.
I hope to goodness we can get settled I am glad you are not discouraged. I dont want you to be but there are others that wont always keep from being so. I hope Roberts will

get his vacation for I know he needs it. Edw got your letter this AM. Perhaps this week you will hear and yet something for Sunday but will wait again, I suppose if nothing does come. It will soon be the first of Sept and things ought to work out I am lovingly, Helen

PS 
Yes I got the $50 you sent me in July. It seems too bad to have to spend 1500 or 20.00 for books that will only be good for a few weeks. What do,

1820 Clay St Aug. 31, 1906.
My Dear Husband,
Your letter with Mr Wheeler's enclosed came today. It looks as if Wellington was not to be had at this present time at least. Chapman I guess seems to be the place now unless something else turns up for us. Dr Thayer is not home yet is to home tomorrow I think.
I will not be able to see

him before next week. I think we must get settled as soon as possible before cold weather comes, I am not able to do anything about taking roomers to help out as we are so uncertain ourselves, I am not strong enough to do much but if we were to be here all winter I would do this. Mrs. E.S. Johnston spent teusday with me on her way home from her fathers. Mrs Ott. from Onaga has been visiting here in Topeka.

she did not call here but was out at Mrs Clarks. She told them that Mr Ayers was going to go back to England I think in the spring and that they want unclear. Mrs Johnston said she told her the same thing. Mrs Ott. is one of the trustees and in with the Grover tribe so perhaps they might be something in it. Still I suppose we cannot wait untill spring on this uncertainty. Our weather has been cooler for a few

days now. I cant bear to think of the time it maybe untill you are at home again. We are trying to get Zaidee ready to go away, and I am as usual so tired I can hardly keep up. Just think of it Mary runs away and you tell her she must not do so again she says "I will Mama."
I guess Howard has given up school this year. I feel sad about it as I want to be through with one in school. With Love Your Wife Helen Everett.

1820 Clay St. Topeka Ks.
My Dear Aunt Mary,
I have thought of writing to you every day for some time but get so little time.
Mary has been very cross and sick a good part of the time the last month and so that has taken much of my time. Edward has not been himself lately and has been cross so you see I have the two babies to look after when one is not crying the other one is.
After Zaidee left I then had the problem of fall sewing for the other school

(2.)
children and Margaret has grown the last year so that everything has to be altered. Roberts thanks to you and the cousins has not had to have much to start with so I can wait for his wants for a time.
Last week I managed to make Edward a little checked suit which looks very nice on him.
I am going to try and make Margaret a school coat this week out of a brown broadcloth skirt of Zaidee's and so it goes.
I am writing this while the children are finishing their breakfast but I will have to leave it now for a while and get them ready and off to school.
Roberts did not go to

school this morning as he has headache and will rest and go this afternoon.
We are thinking now that J E  may be home next week for a few days but he is not sure of it. He is very anxious to be home again but feels as if he must hang on where he is untill something else is sure. I think he has perhaps told you we are hoping to get an opportunity to come before the Church at Wellington but it may not be possible to do so or at least for several weeks yet. The question

(4)
is had we better try to visit for this opening or not.
I have had three of our old Onaga friend visit me this summer at different times each one spending the day. I was glad to see them and the visit did me good as unclear did not get out of the home to visit any.
We are having nice warm weather here yet with a little suspicion of the cold that is to come. Our Kansan falls are beautiful and I do enjoy these sunny bright autumn days with the abundance of all the good things from the loving fathers hand
Kansas has been blessed this year with good crops and people are happy.

(5.)
we are expecting Eddie Everett here tomorrow as he is on the College football team which plays here with Washburn. 
We call him Edward the third. Zaidee seems to be doing nicely with her school and thinks she will like it and enjoy the work. I hope next year she may be able to go on with her work in Washburn. I have had Mary pictures taken will have them soon and will send one when I get there. She is getting a big girl now and will soon be two years old. Zaidee is nineteen years today

(6.)
how time flies. J.E. will soon be away four months and yet the time has gone swiftly. 
We will all be glad to see him again and how nice it will be to be settled again.
Well it is after nine oclock and I must go to work, the dishes seems to wait as well as the picking up and putting to place the usual Monday morning book a magaym &c.
I think I have taken cold as I feel so tired and hate to move around my cheek is swollen up from toothache so I guess I will have to try and rest a little today if I can. I will be glad to hear from you when you can write it seems a long time

7
since I had your last letter.
Mary is saying Mama Rock and insisting on it. I will say good bye for this time.
With a heartful of love,
Your neice,
Helen Everett.
Oct. 8. 1906.

My Dear Aunt Mary,

I think of you so much these days and also of the trip of last summer. Our weather here is very very warm and we do not have the rain to cool the atmosphere as you do in the east

JE left here thursday AM. to take a five weeks course in the University of Chicago. I hope he may be able to words may be missing at fold unclear church & every other kind of care and enjoy this brief time of study. He has been wanting to do this for so long that we left at the expence of other things he had better do this this summer. Now that he

2 

has gone I dont want him to worry over things.
The Pastoral work here in this place keeps him so busy and takes so much of his strength hat he does not have the time or the energy to give to study he ought to have He will stay with cousin Mary Alice & she wanted him to take Edw & he did so and Zaidee is in Chicago also it leaves us just four at home. Roberts is words missing at fold at the depot he is busy all the time. He does not make much out of it but it is good outside work and is happier at work. Margaret & little Mary and myself make up the household. The little folks have not been very well

3 

and feel this dreadful hot weather and we are all longing for a cold spell if only for a few days.
I suppose you will hear from JE in a few days after he gets started but thought I would send this along now. I hope you are feeling well and able to get up to the little chapel on the hill. What is Clara doing this summer? How she must miss her mother this first summer of being apart. You must miss her bright cheery calls and the little visits up to the farm. I must get the children a little lunch as Mary says I unclear

4 

she is hungry as can be. We are all a little lonely today without our papa & no church of our own and I am tired and will hardly go to the other church I had compay from the country yesterday that I did not expect and I am tired out today.
I hope you will write J.E and tell him next to going to see you this is the lest thing he could do during his vacation. He wanted to see you again this summer but wanted me to go and we could hardly stand the expence so soon after last year. Perhaps next year we will go

5

again. We feel grateful to cousin for her kindness to us and JE staying with her is such a help and will be so pleasant for him there. 
I wish I could see you & have a good visit and talk matters instead of writing but so glad we can write.
Cousins address is
1920 W. Leland Ave. Chicago, Ill. 
I will so good night for this time. WIth a heartful of love
Your niece,
Helen Everett.
Smith Center KS.
Aug. 1. 1909.

1820 Clay. St. Topeka.
My Dear Aunt Mary,
your letter of the 10th came this afternoon and in J.E. absence I will send a few lines. JE is in Chapman having I think decided to accept the call to this field. Last week tuesday he came home staying until saterday evening. When he came home he did not expect to return untill this week but

Edward and Mary have both been having hard cold and I have been up nights with them a good deal and that makes me feel so tired. 
Miss Anna O. Mead of Onaga spent three days with me a couple of weeks ago I enjoyed her visit so much she is such a good quiet girl and was so good to us always and she said when here she loved us all just as much as she ever did and I am sure we love her and price her friendship

of delight to every member of the family. I am expecting Zaidee home for the holiday we will all be glad to see her and she is anxious to be home again.

 JE. will be home for Christmas and will then decide what we will do about our moving now or wait till spring we would like to be settled once more and not have this rent to pay. I will send your letter on to J.E. in the morning you have perhaps heard from him

very much she has always written to me since we left Onaga.

 I must close now and write J.E. a few lines so he will get it tomorrow.

With a heartful of love

 your neice,

Helen Everett.

My Dear Aunty Mary
I will add a little to J.E.s letter if I can this morning. We have been to breakfast yet and Mary is still asleep but may waken up in a minute or so as I hardly ever get away from her in the mornings and have her asleep. Life recurs so full for me all the time I do not have much leisure time 

I have been wanting to write you for a long time. I dont think we have ever thanked ou for the Ladies Home Journal again this year I do enjoy it so much and I thank you for it very much. That was such a helpful box of things you sent us and everything 

sideways at top:
will prove the medicine for him, Mary is a sweet brown eyed little tot full of business all the time. I will now close with a heartful of love
Helen Everett

so usefull. I find it hurts me to sew so much and still I must keep it up as it takes so much of it to go even half way around. I see JE does not say anything in his letter in regard to our going to give up the work here in Severy I am sorry about this but there has seemed a misfit from the start and we have felt the unresponsive atmosphere all the while. If we can find something soon I think we will feel that it is the best thing to do. J.E. has never been appreciated here one bit and he has tried to do good work. JE will write you fully about it soon.   We are both wishing that some opening would open for us where we would feel we could find or buy a home as we both feel we do not want to be on the move this way. I sometimes feel this last week like saying we will get us a little home in Topeka and trust for an opening

for the future. JE is not strong and is looking badly. I wish I could see and have a visit with JM and talk matters over. I think after this experience I would be more willing for him to be out of the ministry than I ever have before providing he could teach or do something when we might be settled and have a home; and perhaps a settled feeling of permancy would be a feeling of restfulness that would mean better health. I am afraid this is rather a doleful letter but you seem to be the one nearest to us and we feel you are interested in what we are doing and in our prospects  There is no feeling on our part of sorrow at leaving here, —
sideways at top:
but I hope he will. He will not want me to worry you over our affairs. Margaret is developing into a very sweet girl and things are opening up to her and is learning a great deal in school as well as out. Edward has had a very hard time with the whooping cough and we are hoping warm weather

on the other hand a feeling that it is best and we are glad that things are settled as they are. Our hope is now that something will be found to do soon before JE gets discouraged. Mr. Thayer wrote us yesterday that he was afraid he has not anything in view for us as the churches seemed better supplied than usual but then there are changes always and our turn will come I am sure if we are to have a church again. 
Mary is up and I must get her dressed as Minnie is ironing and her papa somehow does not fill the bill as well as her mama I am sure you will enjoy your telephone and should think it would save you a great many steps and be a source of comfort to you. We have been having dark rainy cold weather here for several weeks but the sun is shining this morning and brightens up everything. I do not know if JE will let me send this or not

Ottawa, July 13th 06

My Dear Mrs Everett, 

 I have almost lost track of you and for fear I will altogether I must write you a line to tell you of our whereabouts. We came to Ottawa in April and have been here ever since waiting for Ive? to get ready to have us come where he is located, in Collinsville, Ind. Ter. but he has been unable to get any sort of a comfortable place for us to live, so has decided that we should stay in Ottawa until something better turns up. Who is the agent at Collins-

2

ville, and it is a good position, but an ungodly place to live, and he says he would not think of having us some there. Well will probably not remain there long, but we will stay in Ottawa now for the rest of the year, and will go to housekeeping as soon as our goods arrive, which will be in a day or two, as they have been shipped from Coffeyville where they have been in storage since we left. We have been spending these weeks with Mame and have had a fine time. It seems pretty good to get back to Ottawa, altho' we would have gone to unclear at any time notwithstanding the inconvenience, if he had said the

2

ward, but he could not make up his mind to drag us down into that hot place and not a decent house to shelter us. We say he is awfully blue, and we are so sorry for him, but he says he is feeling fine, and can stand it better than we could. I have not heard from you for so long, I am quite anxious to know how you all are and if you are still in Severy. Do write at once and tell us all about yourselves. We are real well and enjoying life yet pretty well. Loyal is much better than he was a year ago, and is anxious

to get at the hard job of moving and settling again. We here rented a lovely little cottage of 6 rooms, with lots of nice shade, plenty of fruit and a very pretty house, so we will be very happy here and we are only one block from Mama's, so we can see each other every day. She is well now, and the children are getting to be great big girls, Francis? is going out to western Ks, to spend the rest of the summer with a friend of Mama's. She is a nervous little thin creature, doesn't eat much, and we think the change will be good for her. Elizabeth is almost 4 years old, and is a beautiful child, very lively and talkative?

and happy. Armior? is in N. Carolina will spend a year there, and we expect to go down there and spend part of the winter, Won't that be nice? He says he cannot come home, and we must come and see them. The 1st of January Arm takes? a church, and will be settled, so we can go and see them. He is in love with the south, and he says the people there reciprocate and think he is about the nicest yankee they ever met so they "hitch" well, and he is living well and enjoying life and his work, immensely.

Arm? says he is homesick to see us, as he never was away half so long, before, and he wants us to come and see what nice people he has found and how cordially we will be treated. I am sure we will enjoy it, and are looking forward with great pleasure to the trip.  We mean to have Ive? go with us for a rest for him, and I suppose we can go with little expense. Now dear Mrs. Everett do write us immediately and tell Mr E. to write too, Loyal wants to hear from him. He will be 76 years old in a few days, and we want to celebrate a little if it isnt too hot. I do wish you could come and visit us while we are in Ottawa, Contyan?

4
I must tell you that I saw Miss Althelta? Reinhard of Onaga acquaintance, during the Assembly. She has a sick brother living here and she visited them during Assembly. I had a nice visit with her, and we spoke of you & wished that we knew more about you. She has a nice position at Belich? and seems very happy in her work. She had a young man in "tow" but I could not quite decide whether he was a real beau or not. She looks well and was beautifully dressed, and I enjoyed her very much. She knew

very little Onaga news. So if you know any tell me. All send love to you all, and hope to hear from you real soon. Address us at Ottawa, Kan., 1062 Walnut St.
P.S. We have a very nice young man at our church now. A Mr. Strong, perhaps Mr. Everett knows him. He is very well liked by our people. I suppose you have heard of course, about our Mr. Benson being senator, We came here from Washington Saturday, and had a big reception.  Well good bye. I must stop. Yours in love, 
M. Wiley

77 Atlantic Ave.
Long Beach Calif
Aug 20. 12
My Dear Mrs Everett

I decided I would write letters to night and pay some of my debts and I find some that are older than your letter but I am going to write you first. I did so enjoy your letter and hearing about your family. You say your life seems full of the uneventful that dont count

I think you are very much mistaken just see what your children doing, you are teaching them to be good men and women and sending them out in the world to be great blessings to others.
How I wish you could visit me here and have a good rest, for this is the very best place to rest in you ever saw. I like to go and lie on the sand and listen to the roar of the ocean and I enjoy going in the surf too. I expect to stay here another winter Will probably go back to Kans in the spring but I hardly expect to live in Kiowa again because I have to make my living and I do not see any way to make it then now for other parties all doing so near the same work that I did well their is not enough work there for two, but where ever I live I hope that some day you will visit me, soon your children will be large enough to keep house for a while and you can just slip away and have a good visit, and just think how many there are to welcome you when you return. When I go back to my house there

will be no one to welcome me, mine is the life that does not count
Rev CC McCoy is pastor of our church at Kiowa and I am told he is doing a good work Kiowa has a Christian Church and a Baptist Church now. It was sad indeed about Mr Stromish, he was a dear good man. Mrs Cranston and Mr and Mrs Guirghton are visiting in South Ana and this week Mr. Singleton is so much better than when he came Sun. Mr and Mrs Justur and children are visiting her father and sister in South Ana, and spent one day in Long Beach. Mrs. Geo Wills and Glure? and wife will have a

2

few weeks ago they live in Arizona. Mrs. Wilson and children are spending the summer on the ranch Mr and Mrs Rumsing and Jessie visited in Kansas this summer and expect to spend the winter with Marston and Edina Wells in Florida and if they like there will make it their home. Milton and Willa Wells have another baby girl, three girls they have and one boy. Mrs Geo Wells was here when your letter came and she sends her love to you

and all the family she said we never appreciated you and Mr Everett until you were gone. I know of two that did, my father and I
You remember the Michmans? Clyde was married June 12, and went to Chicago and took a summer course of study at the University and will teach at Lion Kansas this winter. Guy graduated at the Boston school of Oratory and will teach in Boston this winter  Will?  graduated last year and taught last winter. Ray is the best looking out of the boys and will graduate next year. 
I havent been out of Long Beach since my visit to South Ana in the spring, but have had a lovely summer here, can not realize that it is almost Sept time certainly does on [[going>]] I have been here fourteen months and it doesn't seem half that long, it will be spring tie again, and time for me to go home before I get really Mr and Mrs Belehm and Bud Sawyer brother and sister of my brother in law and from the Auburn? neighborhood

started home this morning after a two months visit in Long Beach with their children I am so anxious for my sister to come here for one winter and enjoy the pleasant winter we have here, but she thinks it is too far from home. Well must quit and go to bed write me again when you have time, and remember if I should locate in Calif you are to make us a good long visit. 
My regards to Mr Everett and all the family, and a heart full of love for your help

 from Retta? Cruchnor?

Mrs. J.E. Everett
Smith Centre

Ks

Dear friends - Have tho't of you frequently even tho I haven't written and was real glad to hear from you once again.
You are no doubt hearing from many of your friends thru

your little leaflets sent out -- I shall be so glad to get a copy of the poems   Have intended sending sooner but in the holiday rush just postponed letter writing 
We have had a beautiful Christmas Even the weather was ideal. We are having our first storm now. It is really quite

wintry today

 We are all enjoying good heath here now. Sister Grace has had a very serious illness - appendicitis and almost peritonitis She had two operations but is about well now -- She is at her home but rather frail yet
 John her husband owns a lumber yard at Climax and they live here.

Kathleen is ass't Principal in Eureka High School She lives with Mrs. Peffer. -- She is running the paper now. = Her children are well and Ruth keeps house &cares for them so she is doing the work Mr. Peffer was at when he died.

 Severy is slowly improving as a town. It has several nice house built since

stationery heading again
you were here. We have an electric light plant and current walk all over town. 

 We took in twelve new members in our Church yesterday five of them were a family from Western Park, "Jewell who have recently bo't the Moses Jordan home and moved in town

families in the past three years. John Jordan's Will Adams' and several more are in Calif & Oregon now. Turners in Colorado. Mr. Ed Brady you no doubt remember him has been very ill for two years has some stomach trouble He is quite bad no we hardly expect him to live

Well I must close seems there

we have a real good pastor now D.D. McSkimmings - He is a good all around man and we have him all the time = Park Church has so few supporters any more so many have moved

 We miss Myrta Maddox and Jennie Evans more than any other tho we have lost several other

should be more news but people have changed here so there are more new people that the old ones you knew. Our womans Club is almost disbanded this winter I am sorry to say I believe we are selfish and prefer our own books and tho'ts. Have been home very close myself -- Well write when you can Love to the children from 

 Martin & Margaret.

December 21 1919
Mrs Everett
Dear friend it is the time of year that I am thinking of all my friends how are you all this winter it has been so cold and the roads so bad that I dont suppose you have been to Topeka when you do come write me a card and I will have a cup of coffee for you it seems a long time we had a visit we are as well as usual but have to stay in very close it is after ten oclock and I have several cards to write wishing you all a merry christmas and happy new year with much love  your friend Lear Seeley

Oakland, Calif.
Nov. 30 - 1920.
My dear sister and family: -
I surely am thinking a lot these days, about how nice it would be if we all could be together once, and I know you and Katie surely enjoyed your visit together. I wrote to Katie and as I have rec'd no reply I persume she is with you now. Hope you both write soon.

3/ a snowy Xmas.
The children are both fine. They don't like Oakland or Oakland schools nearly as well as Seattle. I think they miss their old playmates. I am trying to make Helen a new dress for Xmas. and never again, please send me over your washing and scrubbing. I never did like sewing.

2. We have been having a little rain. but it really hasn't been no bad weather here as yet. The sun shines nearly every day. The mornings and evenings feel a bit chilly tho. and a fire quite welcome. It really seems odd to me yet, holidays and now snow. It has been quite a few years since I saw

4. Douglas is quite a big boy now. You would think so if you could see him. I wrote to Howard and will write to Zaidee a little later. 
Write me soon. I want this to get away when post man comes. so will make it rather short.
Lots of Love to all.
Lovingly.
Lotta Monahan
156. 8th st.

Palmville Nov 3" 1920
My Dear Sister Ella-
Carrie sent your letter for me to read and I was very glad to hear from you. She also brought the one you wrote two years ago. I intended to write you then but did not get at it. The last I heard from you you were going to some Hospital for an operation but you did not say where and what for, so I could not write you but I often wondered about you and how you all were. I would like very much to see How and wish he

might get here on some of his trips. I'm not much interested in Tractors but would like to see him. also Zaidee and you. Frank used to write me so much about you and the children. I have the last letter he wrote me in my scrap Book and I often read it. I was married 28 years ago. Nov. 1st 1920. to one of the best men living. I unclear but we surely? lived together 15 year. then God took him. but I cannot understand why. for we were so happy together. He taught school when we were married. but he over gave that up and went in the Mercantile Businiss. Had a

2

Store at Saxton also the Post Office at Saxton then we built another Store at Palmville (about two miles from Saxton) and had them both when he died. Then I sold the one at Saxton, and kept the one at Palmville, where I'm still living, and have the Store. I have two Clerks, a man & Girl all the time and in Summer I have two more, a woman to do the house work (as the house is connectid with Store) and a Boy to help in Store. Have had the same help ever since my husband died, so they seem to belong here. The Store is a general country Store mostly Groceries, and some

Dry Goods & notions to supply the Summer trade. We have two Auto Trucks One large and one small one, so we do quite a Business in the Summer. We have had a lovely Fall. hope it will continue nice for a long time yet. Carrie lives about four miles from here, some of the family are here every week. She does not come very often as she has always had a lot to do, and has yet Uncle John Scribner lives with her and he is a great care. He can walk around and help himself but he is old and very childish. Election is own and we are to have a new

3

Prisident. it is to be seen whether he is any better. I have voted three times. Have you? It seems so strange to go and vote. I am not a "Suffagist," but think its all right for the women to vote. How I would enjoy seeing all of you and maybe I can some day. I have no children but the Girl I have has been with me 14 years so she seems almost the same. She is a nice good girl and I hope she can stay with me for a long time. 

 Write me when you can. I'm sorry your health is not good. 
 Lots of love to you all. 
Your Sister Etta Saxe.

Oakland Calif.
Dec. 14 - 21
Dear Sister and all: -
A few lines to let you know we are still living and enjoying fairly good health, also we are enjoying Gods sunshine nearly every day, Of course our nights are sometimes frosty and mornings a bit foggy, but the day itself

2. turns out so fine we are all so glad we forget about the unpleasant part and think only of the sunshine. How fast the year has gone by, the world is such a busy place any more, it seems impossible to keep track of time. Nothing like being busy to keep one out of mischief, so they say, and I can frankly vouch for its truthfulness.

3/. Expect you will have a houseful at Xmas time, I think that is one time of the year it is grand to have folks (real) to spend the time with you. We have been away from the folks so long we feel something like aliens, "but don't you dare "feel" that way. - - Sent you people a box of California Fruits and I

4. hope you will enjoy them as much as we did to send them. Wishing you all the Merriest of Xmas and Happiest of New Year.
Sister Lotta.
9239 - C? st.

Cannon Falls Minn
June. 28. 1928.
My Dear Sister
It seams a long time while we are waiting for you to come home and I hop it will be the first of next week. we was sure sorry that you had to go through with such a hard time. so soon after the recent one you had mabey now you will get well and strong again. I sure was surprised when I asked J.E. how Helen was and he sayed she was in the Hospital Ira and I are filing good now after our long trip of five days and four nights and we think it is Delightfull hear hear now too see the big green fields and trees too see it all come so lovely at the same time it is nice and cool hear today and we are all well except

Oliver who has been sick since he came Monday, but he is much beter today and is planing on going home tom-orrow Mary and I are getting along fine togather she is some coock and an all around fine girl we think J.E. and Ira and myself went too show last night little Kingdom Come which was real good we dont go too the movies verry often but I gess it is alright too have a good laugh once and a while O. yes we had beet greens out of your garden for dinner today and thay was fine Ira is going to water your tomatoes good tonight hoping you are not suffering so much pain now and that we will all be togather soon and have good visits with our best love and a big hug and kiss from all the family

Katheyn P. Norton.

[1928]
My Dear Mrs. Everett, -
I have just finished talking with Mary and she says you didnt have the operation you had planned on. Im sorry anything else had to be done but hope you are feeling better now.
Mary says she did lots of work while you were both away and she still is doing lots, I told her Id be down to inspect it when it was all done.
Ive been getting a few letters

out of the way the last few days & receiving unexpected callers from out of town - This morning I got? and sent a wedding present for a girl whose family and the Scrivers have been very intimate for years - we hope to go to her wedding next Tues. Arthur tried on his dress suit this morning and thot by holding his breath while he got into it he might wear it. I hope the buttons are strong. I told him I wanted him to wear it at Irenes wedding, I have heard that we are to have a dinner at Red Wing but do not know for sure, if so he may not want to wear it. I hope you get out in time to be there.
We are having lots of excitement up on the hill now with a house going up & pretty soon another one will start - the children are a sight by night on account of playing in the gravel & sand all day long.
We are hoping to go over for Commencement Sunday, have been planning our picnic dinner and hope it will

be a nice day for a picnic - We had hoped for rain the last couple of days but it just sprinkled everything is so dry -
Mrs Clifford just called me & said Mrs. Valentine's brother died, the one who is married, he had a stroke. I dont think I even know him by sight.
We drove to Mpls Wed night & heard Donald M. in recital, it was wonderfully fine the Lees went with us -
I hope you will get well fast now but enjoy the rest while you can -
With love
Katherine L. Scriver -

Dear Helen -
Enjoyed so much your good letter. Do it again and as often as possible. Edward must certainly be pleased to have that fine trip - it will do him much good I am sure. Suppose they will soon all be home for the holiday season. Gertrude is here for the

Holidays. Does not have to go out again until January third. We shall all have Christmas dinner at mother's. This will be the last time we shall do that, I think, as she hasn't the strength for such things any more.
We send our love and wishes for a happy time to all the family. Yours,
Bertha L. Glazier

WASHBURN GLEE CLUB TO TAKE BIG CHRISTMAS TRIP
First Concert to Be Given in Topeka.
Will Sing in Kansas City, St. Joseph and Many Kansas Points — To Travel 1,000 Miles.
text
Edward Everett Accompanist.
Edward Everett is the pianist, and will go with the men on the trip. He is a first-class accompanist, and adds much to the effectiveness of the men's singing, according to Mr. Post.
A special feature of the concert is the "a Cappella" or unaccompanied singing, which comprises one part of the program. 
text
All Are Vaccinated.
Vaccination is one of the requirements for the men, before they will be allowed to take the trip. This is done to prevent any trouble in case some of the cites visited have quarantine regulations to prevent the spread of the disease. 
Professor Post, who will accompany the men on part of the trip, was a menber of the Washburn glee club which made the Santa Fe reading room trip to the Pacific coast in 1915. Since leaving Washburn he has studied in the East, giving special attention to club singing.
text

Thursday evening
Dear Folks: -
I suppose you think perhaps the silence is getting rather long. Honestly though I simply can't seem to find time to write letters. Believe me they're not going to let anyone loaf at this school.
Well. I'll tell you about the mess I got into unclear. When the conductor took my ticket I asked him whether I changed at Randolf and he said no went went straight through. Well, I took his word for it and as I have no sense of direction I didn't realize which way I was going and consequently after we had ridden quite a ways out of Randolf I wondered why we weren't at Carleton or Northfield and about the same time I discovered we were nearly to St. Paul! What was I to do with only 56¢! I was afraid I wouldn't be able to locate Ed. so when the brakeman came through I asked him the quickest way to get back to where I started and he told me to get off at St. Paul and take the first train back. I told him I realized that was the proper thing but that I was broke. Well we went on & said he'd be back in a minute. Well, since I'm young

and innocent looking, I guess he thought he'd take a chance so he came back gave me his name, address & two dollars. Wasn't that nice of him? I left S.P. at 3 and got here at 4:30. A good trip for 15 miles. I had to eat part of my food? for lunch. I've found out that you never can tell about the weather.
The fed? went just fine. I could only by cutting & cutting make five pieces of chicken out of what was left so I only had had five beds - Esther? & Harriet Lucille & Voila and Mary.
Daddy, you'll just have to come this way. Please do -
O, yes, I called Ed. but of course he wasn't home & I called at the lib. but it wasn't open. I got a letter form Ed. today - he of course gave me his programe, told me his phone number & what street cars go by his house.
Father are you through working in the printing office?
Perle B. didn't make a sorritory. Helen K. & Thelma have their hair bobbed. Helen looks good & Thelma doesn't. Laura Hart is wearing long dresses.

I had to quit last night and go to house meeting. Then we had a fire drill.
Maybe I'll get 8 hr. in French. If we are smart enough etc, she is going to try and give us 2 semesters work in one, but I'm afraid I'll be doing good if I get four hours credit.
Say, wasn't it cold last night, I nearly froze! They didn't turn the heat on until 6:30.
Well, I must close and get this to the P.O. before class.
Lots of love
Mary
P.S. Please come this way!

postmark NORTHFIELD MINN.
OCT 6 1923

Mrs. J.E. Everett
Cannon Falls
Minn

Kiowa, Kans
May 25 - 1898.
Dear Aunt Anna and Aunt Mary.
I received your welcome letter May. 24. I am taking music lessons now and so is Howard and Papa. We have a girl now her name is Leda Gillig. I like the vacation best. I will be up stairs next year in the seventh grade. I was rank one all last term. We have got eleven little chickens. Roberts has got the "whipping cough" as he calls it. In one month Howard will be 13 years old. He has got a job of taking three cows to pasture. One of them

is ours he does not get any pay for that but he gets 50 cents a month for the other two. We have a nice little pony his name is Russel. We have a little garden which Howard takes care of. I will close for this time hoping to hear from you soon.
Your loving niece
Zaidee Everett.

Kiowa, Kans
May. 20. 1898.
Dear Aunt Anna.
I love the flowers and I like to pick them. 
When I was going out to Mr. Crewdson's ranch I saw some prairie dogs come out of their holes and I heard them make a noise and then go back in their holes. There are lots of rabbits out here. I have to take naps every afternoon until I get to go be a big boy. The roses are in blooming. I am glad you sent me those Sunday School papers every week. Zaidee read the papers to me

Mamma has got some new plants. I gave Mrs. Holloway a kiss for a colice (a plant). Mamma gave me a Ganna?. Papa is taking music lessons now. Zaidee is writing this letter for me.
Here are some kisses for you.
circles with four lines criss-crossed through them--image
Put this one on your cheek
Your loving nephew
John Roberts Everett

Kiowa Kans. 
May 25 98
Dear Aunt Anna and Mary

 In one month I will be 13 years old. I got your letter about this time yesterday (10 A.M.) I have got a job of taking three cows over to the pasture about a quarter of a mile I get 50 cts a mo per head for two. One is papa's and I do not of course get anything for it. We have a nice pony seven or eight years old. I ride him over to the pasture. We are all pretty well excepting Roberts who has the "whipping cought" as he calls it. I will graduate

from this school in three years in 1900. Next year I will be in Papa's Room as he is Prof. School has been out for about 2 weeks I can play a little on the organ as I have been taking lessons for nearly a year. Uncle Will is getting along pretty well. Aunt Maggie is guess is getting along all right. She has been teaching school this year but I don't know whether it is out yet or not as we have not heard from her. I guess they are all getting along all right since Als? grandma died. Grandpa and Douglass went to Canada

3
along in the winter but is back now. Lewis left here the first or second week in February and only writes to me once in a month and he ought oftener. We have a nice garden of which I take care of. I have to milk now since Lewis has gone. I cannot think of anything else so I will close 
With Love
Howard E.
P.S. Please write very soon.

Kiowa, Kans
Oct 9. 1898
Dear Aunt Mary and Aunt Anna.
I thought I would write you a little letter. It is raining so Papa and Howard did not go to church this evening. Yesterday was my birthday. I got two aprons and a pair of shoes. I was eleven years old.
Howard wore long pants today for the first time. He is in Papa's room now. I am up stairs. 
I study Geography, Arithmetic, Spelling, Reading and Grammar.

Mamma gives Roberts three cents a week and me ten cents for taking care of Baby. Roberts takes Papa's dinner to school every Friday after-noon and he goes up town all alone. 
I guess I will close for this time. So Good Bye
Your loving Niece
Zaidee Everett
Write soon.

Kiowa Kansas
Oct. 9 1897?
Dear Aunties: -
To-night is Sunday night and it is raining so that there will be no church.  I am now in papa's room and study Latin English Arithmetic and Physical Geography.  I wore long pants for the first time to-day.  Saturday was Sister's birthday and I gave her an apron for a present.  She was 11 years old.  I am going up to Osawatomie at Christmas to visit Lewis.  Mamma told me to ask you what would be good to take as a preventive of diphtheria.  Cases of it are reported a few miles of us on all sides.  I have a pig and have been saving up money to buy feed for it this winter.  We have a horse now and I ride it after my cows.  We have a few chickens and a few are mine.  As soon as our cow is fresh, I will have to milk it.  I learned to milk before she went dry.

I cannot think of any more to write so I will close
With Love to All
Howard

Kiowa, Kansas, Oct. 9, 1898,
My Dear Aunties: -
That was a nice little jacket that you sent to Margaret, Thank you for it.
I got a rubber ball Saturday, Zaidee had a birthday yesterday.  Mama gives me three cents on every Friday night for shaking the baby every day when the other folks are at school, so that Mama can do her work.  But when she wakes up Mama has to take her.  I shake her some Saturdays and some Sundays.  I can come home from church all alone.  It is five blocks.
I go up to town alone.  One night I went up alone and hunted all over town for tomatoes.  Once I went to Mr. Waltners and back and got a box of Sardines,

and got back quicker than they expected me. - Margaret too,
Our cow isn't giving milk now, and I go over to Mrs. Holloway's after milk, - one block.
I take papa's dinner to school on Fridays, but one Friday it rained and Howard had to take it.
Your loving nephew
Roberts

Kiowa, Kans
Nov.6.1898
Dear Aunts:

 I received your letter yesterday. I have not received any dress and think it rather strange. I hope the cousins enjoyed their visit at Omaha. There are quite a few cases of diphtheria within six or seven miles of town. Mamma has the Quinsy. She has had it lanced two times. I had my picture taken this evening. I will send you one soon. Baby laughs out aloud and

crows. Roberts can count up to thirty. He is getting to be quite a big boy. I will close now with lots of love for both. 
Your loving niece
Zaidee Everett.

1899
Kiowa
Kans
Jan 12-1899
Dear Aunties:

 I do thank you for the jacket you sent Margaret, and for the spoon and the silver thimble and the cup and the handkerchief and the pin. I did write you a letter a long time ago and I have been waiting for you to answer it for a long while. Mamma said to thank you the Ladies Home Journal, and I do thank you for the testaments. Papa has gone just across

the street to bury a little girl who had something like the Diptherial Croup. I am real sick with the sore throat.

 To my loving dear Aunties

John Roberts Everett

Kiowa Kans
Jan. 29, 1899
Dear Aunties:
We received your letter and are glad you are all well. Roberts is lots better. Mamma is going to get Margaret in short clothes now and then we can put her in the Baby-tender. I got a pen-knife, a trinket box, a pair of slippers, a silk handkerchief, three neckties, a dollar and the thimble that you sent me for Xmas. I like the thimble very much and I thank you for it. I could'nt use a thimble before Christmas but now I can't get along without it. There is a man lecturing his name is John. P.D. John. I guess I will close for this time So
Goodbye
Your loving niece
Zaidee Everett

Kiowa Kansas
Jan 29 1899.
Dear Aunties:
Roberts and Sister started to write to you and wanted me to write to you too. We study Book-Keeping now and have written in our Day-Book, Journal & Ledger. I like it pretty well. We quit Physical Geography before Christmas. I bought me a second-hand saddle and like it very much. We have a nice riding-horse and I like to ride better than anything else. For Christmas I got a shirt, hat, lantern a pin that you sent me and a nice tie to wear it in. Papa got a hat, a moustache cup & saucer, and a comb from me. Mamma got a double-boiler & a box of nice hair-pins. Roberts got a whole lot of things a doll, a pair of slippers, a silver napkin-ring, a silver spoon from you, and a lot of other things. When he was sick he got two dollars for taking a tea spoonful of medicine and Mamma gave him a calf but he said that he would rather have the calf be part of Mamma's, and the doctor said he would have his pony brought from his claim in the strip for Roberts to ride. Hoping you will write very soon
I remain yours
With Love
Howard.
